solution_text: Left unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis
default:
Left-on-left sacral torsion (a forward sacral torsion about the left oblique axis).

Reason: positive seated flexion on the left indicates a left oblique axis; the shallow right sulcus with a superior right ILA (i.e., posterior/inferior left ILA) is consistent with the sacral base anterior on the left (L on L).
alternative: Left unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Right unilateral sacral extension (unilateral sacral extension about the middle transverse axis).

Reasoning: A shallow (decreased) right sacral sulcus indicates the right sacral base is posterior, and a superior right inferior lateral angle (ILA) reflects posterior/upward motion of that sacral side — findings consistent with a right-sided unilateral sacral extension. The seated flexion test being positive on the left is a contralateral finding commonly seen with this pattern.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Right unilateral sacral flexion (anterior rotation of the right sacral base about the superior transverse axis).

Reasoning: A shallow (anterior) right sacral sulcus with a superior right inferior‑lateral angle indicates the right sacral base is anterior (flexed) on that side. Unilateral sacral extension would produce a deep sulcus and an inferior ILA on the affected side, so “right unilateral sacral extension” is inconsistent with your findings. The left‑positive seated flexion test is compatible with a right‑sided sacral dysfunction.
raw_c:
Yes — the best fit is a right unilateral sacral extension (right sacral base posterior/counternutated).

Reasoning: a shallow right sacral sulcus with a superior/right ILA means the right sacral base is posterior (extension) and the right apex/ILA is elevated. A seated flexion test positive on the opposite side (left) is typical for a unilateral sacral extension whose transverse axis lies contralaterally, and the bilateral lumbar paraspinal tenderness is a common associated finding.
raw_d:
Most likely a right unilateral sacral extension.

Reasoning: a shallow right sacral sulcus with a superior right ILA indicates posterior rotation (extension) of the sacrum on the right. A left-positive seated flexion test suggests a left-sided sacroiliac/pelvic restriction that can accompany a compensatory right-sided sacral extension.

question: A 27-year-old woman with no significant medical history comes to the clinic reporting upper back pain that worsens with prolonged studying. She describes a non-radiating, achy pain rated as 7/10. Physical examination reveals normal upper extremity strength and range of motion bilaterally. Upon palpation, a localized area of tenderness is identified on the left side, specifically at the posterolateral aspect of the transverse process just medial to the scapula's inferior angle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
options: A. Serratus posterior superior strain B. Rhomboid major muscle spasm C. T7 posterior tender point D. Latissimus dorsi muscle strain E. Scapulothoracic bursitis F. T6 posterior tender point G. T12 posterior tender point H. T8 posterior tender point I. Myofascial pain syndrome involving the trapezius J. T9 posterior tender point
default: Rhomboid muscle strain (likely rhomboid major) — postural myofascial strain causing focal tenderness along the medial border/inferior angle of the scapula with normal strength/ROM, classic for “study”/postural strain.
raw_a:
Most likely: a T7 posterior tender point. 

Reason: The inferior angle of the scapula overlies the T7 vertebral level (spinous process), so localized tenderness just medial to the inferior scapular angle at the posterolateral transverse process corresponds to the T7 posterior thoracic tender point — not T8.
raw_b:
Most probable diagnosis: rhomboid major strain / myofascial pain (trigger point) of the rhomboid major.

Reasoning: the described focal tenderness “just medial to the scapula’s inferior angle” corresponds to the medial border/insertion region of rhomboid major. The pain is postural (worse with prolonged studying), non‑radiating, with normal neuro and ROM — all consistent with a localized muscle strain or myofascial trigger point. Serratus posterior superior is deeper and higher on the thorax and would not typically produce this exact focal medial scapular border tenderness. Management: posture correction, stretching/strengthening, NSAIDs, heat, and PT/trigger‑point release if needed.
raw_c:
Most probable diagnosis: rhomboid major (rhomboid) muscle strain.

Reasoning: The focal tenderness at the medial border near the scapula’s inferior angle corresponds to the rhomboid major insertion. Pain that’s localized, nonradiating, worse with prolonged poor posture/studying, and with normal strength/ROM and neuro exam is typical of a myofascial/rhomboid strain rather than radiculopathy or intra‑articular shoulder disease.
raw_d:
Most likely: a posterior thoracic (T8) tender point — i.e., a focal somatic dysfunction at the T8 transverse process. 

Reason: the described focal, nonradiating point tenderness at the posterolateral aspect of the transverse process just medial to the scapula’s inferior angle corresponds anatomically to the T7–T8 region (commonly T8), is worsened by posture, and occurs without neurologic deficit or global motion loss — findings typical of a thoracic posterior tender point rather than a diffuse muscle strain.

question: A 39-year-old male with a history of heroin use disorder (now on methadone) presents with a 2-week history of progressive lower extremity edema, fatigue, and hematuria. He is in a stable monogamous relationship and denies current substance use except for methadone. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, scleral icterus, hepatomegaly (14 cm span), acrocyanosis, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. His vital sign show mild hypertension (152/98 mmHg). Laboratory finding include proteinuria with dysmorphic RBCs on urinalysis, and decreased C3 and C4 complement levels. What is the most likely finding expected on renal biopsy?
options: A. Membranoproliferative pattern with double contours B. Diffuse mesangial cell proliferation with capillary wall thickening C. Crescentic glomerulonephritis with fibrinoid necrosis D. Granular subepithelial immune deposits ("spike and dome" appearance) E. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis with podocyte effacement F. Nodular mesangial expansion with Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions G. Linear IgG deposits along glomerular basement membrane H. Glomerular basement membrane thinning and splitting I. Apple-green birefringence on Congo red stain J. Wire loop lesions with hyaline thrombi
solution_text: Diffuse mesangial cell proliferation with capillary wall thickening
default: Granular subendothelial immune-complex deposits with mesangial proliferation and GBM duplication producing a "tram‑track" appearance (membranoproliferative/immune-complex GN with IgG/IgM and C3 on IF).
alternative: Diffuse mesangial cell proliferation with capillary wall thickening
raw_a:
Most likely: membranoproliferative (MPGN) pattern — mesangial and endocapillary proliferation with capillary‑wall thickening and "tram‑track" double contours from subendothelial immune‑complex deposits (granular IgG/C3 on IF).

Reason: history suggesting chronic hepatitis C/immune‑complex disease (low C3 and C4), hematuria/proteinuria and hepatomegaly fit MPGN, which classically shows mesangial proliferation with GBM splitting and subendothelial immune deposits.
raw_b:
Most likely finding: membranoproliferative (immune-complex) glomerulonephritis — granular "lumpy‑bumpy" Ig/C3 deposits with subendothelial electron‑dense immune complexes and "tram‑track" double contours of the GBM on light microscopy.

Reasoning: Hepatomegaly, scleral icterus and risk from prior IV drug use point to chronic hepatitis C with mixed cryoglobulinemia → immune‑complex MPGN; low C3/C4, dysmorphic RBCs and proteinuria fit an immune‑complex GN rather than amyloid (Congo red apple‑green birefringence).
raw_c:
Most likely: membranoproliferative (immune-complex) glomerulonephritis — hypercellular glomeruli with “tram‑track” GBM duplication and granular subendothelial immune‑complex deposits (IgG/IgM and C3) on IF/EM.

Reasoning: IV drug use → hepatitis C with mixed cryoglobulinemia classically causes MPGN. Hypocomplementemia (low C3 and C4), dysmorphic RBCs/proteinuria, hepatomegaly, acrocyanosis (cryoglobulins) all point to immune‑complex MPGN rather than amyloid (Congo red).
raw_d:
Correct — diffuse mesangial proliferation with capillary wall thickening and “tram‑track” double‑contour GBM from subendothelial immune‑complex deposits (membranoproliferative GN). 

Reason: the nephritic picture (hematuria, hypertension), low C3 and C4, and signs of chronic liver disease/IV‑drug exposure point to hepatitis C–associated MPGN (often with cryoglobulinemia), which shows mesangial/endothelial proliferation and GBM splitting on biopsy.

question: A 4-month-old male infant, previously healthy and born at term, is brought to the emergency department via ambulance with breathing difficulties. His symptom began with rhinorrhea, mild fever, and cough for 3 days, progressing to rapid breathing overnight that has worsened over 6 hours. After his parents noticed audible breathing sounds this morning, they called emergency services. The paramedics initiated high-flow oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and confirmed normal blood glucose before transport. Current examination shows: - Temperature: 37.8°C - Respiratory rate: 70 breaths/minute - Heart rate: 160 beats/minute - Oxygen saturation: 90% on 2L supplemental oxygen - Patient is agitated with shallow breathing, nasal flaring, and grunting - Lung examination reveals symmetric coarse breath sounds and wheezes throughout Given this clinical presentation, which arterial blood gas result would be most indicative of impending respiratory failure?
options: A. pH, 7.45; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 35 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 25 mEq/liter B. pH, 7.6; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 25 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 24 mEq/liter C. pH, 7.3; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 55 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 28 mEq/liter D. pH, 7.35; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 50 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 27 mEq/liter E. pH, 7.38; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 48 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 26 mEq/liter F. pH, 7.2; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 40 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 15 mEq/liter G. pH, 7.4; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 45 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 26 mEq/liter H. pH, 7.5; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 30 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 22 mEq/liter I. pH, 7.1; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 65 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 20 mEq/liter J. pH, 7.25; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 60 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 24 mEq/liter
solution_text: pH, 7.4; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 45 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 26 mEq/liter
default:
An ABG showing acute hypercapnic respiratory failure, e.g. pH 7.25, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 55 mmHg, HCO3− ≈24 mEq/L.

Rationale: rising PaCO2 with low pH indicates failing ventilation (ventilatory failure) and worsening gas exchange despite supplemental O2 — the pattern most predictive of impending respiratory failure needing ventilatory support.
alternative: pH, 7.4; partial pressure of carbon dioxide, 45 mm Hg; bicarbonate, 26 mEq/liter
raw_a:
Most indicative ABG: pH ~7.25, PaCO2 ≈ 60 mm Hg, PaO2 ≈ 50–60 mm Hg, HCO3− ≈ 24 mEq/L (acute respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia).

Reason: Rising PaCO2 (hypercapnia) in an otherwise tachypneic infant signals hypoventilation/fatigue and impending respiratory failure; a PaCO2 well above 50–60 mm Hg with acidemia is the key red flag. The values you suggested (pH 7.4, PaCO2 45, HCO3 26) are essentially normal and would not indicate imminent failure.
raw_b:
Most indicative: an ABG showing acute hypercapnic respiratory acidosis — e.g. pH ≈ 7.22, PaCO2 ≈ 60–65 mm Hg, HCO3 ≈ 24–26 mEq/L.

Why: impending ventilatory failure is characterized by rising PaCO2 with only minimal renal compensation (acute respiratory acidosis), so pH falls into the mid‑7.2 range while HCO3 remains near normal. The commonly cited set (pH 7.1, PaCO2 65, HCO3 20) reflects a mixed disorder (concurrent metabolic acidosis) and is not the typical ABG of acute isolated respiratory failure.
raw_c:
No — the most worrisome ABG would show primary respiratory acidosis with hypercapnia and hypoxemia, for example: pH 7.20, PaCO2 65 mm Hg, PaO2 50–55 mm Hg, HCO3– ≈24 mEq/L. 

Reason: infants initially hyperventilate (low PaCO2); rising PaCO2 with falling pH despite supplemental O2 indicates ventilatory failure (fatigue/inadequate ventilation) and impending respiratory failure.
raw_d:
No — the most indicative ABG of impending respiratory failure is pH 7.1, PaCO2 65 mm Hg, HCO3– 20 mEq/L.

Reasoning: impending failure is signaled by rising PaCO2 with respiratory acidosis (inability to ventilate) despite tachypnea. A PaCO2 of 65 with pH 7.1 shows significant acute hypercapnic respiratory failure. The ABG you propose (pH 7.4, PaCO2 45, HCO3– 26) is essentially normal and would not indicate impending respiratory failure.

question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptom. The affected joints feel "stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital sign are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with sign of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show: | Hemoglobin | 12.6 g/dL | | --- | --- | | Leukocyte count | 8000/mm3 | | Segmented neutrophils | 76% | | Eosinophils | 1% | | Lymphocytes | 20% | | Monocytes | 3% | | Platelet count | 360,000/mm3 | | Erythrocyte sedimentation rate | 36 mm/hr | | Serum | | | Antinuclear antibodies | positive | | Rheumatoid factor | negative | Which is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis B. Reactive arthritis C. Seronegative polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis D. Lyme disease E. Psoriatic arthritis F. Rheumatic fever G. Mixed connective tissue disease H. Septic arthritis I. Post-viral arthritis J. Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis
default: Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pauciarticular JIA) — ANA-positive, RF-negative young girl with ≤4 chronically inflamed joints and associated chronic anterior uveitis.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Reasoning: She is a young girl with ≥6 weeks of arthritis involving ≤4 joints (both knees, ankle, wrist), morning stiffness, elevated ESR and positive ANA — the classic pattern for oligoarticular JIA. ANA+ young girls with oligoarticular JIA are at high risk for chronic anterior uveitis (her slit‑lamp findings), which would not be typical for a self‑limited postviral arthritis.
raw_b:
Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pauciarticular JIA).

Reasoning: she is a young girl with ≤4 chronic inflamed joints (both knees, right ankle, wrist) over months, ANA positive and RF negative, mildly elevated ESR, and bilateral chronic anterior uveitis — the classic constellation for oligoarticular JIA. Other entities (systemic JIA, polyarticular RF‑positive JIA, septic or reactive arthritis) are less likely given the absence of daily fevers/rash, RF positivity, acute monoarthritis, or typical post‑GI/GU infection features.
raw_c:
Yes — oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Reasoning: She is a young girl with ≥3 months of arthritis involving 4 joints (both knees, right ankle, right wrist) — meeting the oligoarticular JIA definition (≤4 joints in the first 6 months). Oligoarticular JIA classically affects young girls, is often ANA positive, has an elevated ESR, and is strongly associated with chronic anterior uveitis/iritis (explaining her eye findings). Other diagnoses are less likely: systemic JIA would have quotidian fevers/rash and marked systemic inflammation; polyarticular JIA involves ≥5 joints; septic/reactive arthritis or Lyme disease would have different history/exam and typically different lab clues.
raw_d:
Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Reasoning: symptoms have been progressive for 3 months (chronic arthritis = >6 weeks), with characteristic morning stiffness that improves with activity and objective swelling/tenderness. She’s a young girl with ANA positivity and bilateral anterior uveitis—classic for oligoarticular JIA (≤4 joints in the first 6 months; here: both knees, right ankle and wrist). Post-viral arthritis is typically acute, short-lived and occurs soon after infection (weeks), and is not associated with ANA positivity or chronic uveitis, so it is much less likely.

question: A 17-year-old female presents to the emergency department with worsening abdominal and pelvic pain that began 3 days ago. She describes the pain as diffuse, involving her abdomen, pelvis, and vagina. She also reports vaginal itching and discharge. She works at an ice cream parlor and is sexually active with multiple partners. Her vital sign are: temperature 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure 122/80 mmHg, pulse 82/min, respirations 15/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness, a foul-smelling thin white vaginal discharge, and the patient scratching her vaginal area during the exam. What is the most appropriate first step in management?
options: A. KOH prep B. Urinalysis C. Nucleic acid amplification test D. Urine hCG E. Vaginal pH testing F. Pelvic ultrasound G. Cervical swab and culture H. Complete blood count I. Serum β-hCG J. Wet mount
default:
Obtain a pregnancy test (urine β-hCG) immediately. 

Rationale: any reproductive‑age patient with abdominal/pelvic pain requires pregnancy testing first to rule out pregnancy/ectopic and to guide subsequent diagnostic steps and treatments.
raw_a:
Perform a pregnancy test (urine β-hCG) immediately.

Reason: In any sexually active adolescent with pelvic/abdominal pain you must first rule out pregnancy/ectopic pregnancy — results change imaging needs and management (and antibiotic choices). Pelvic ultrasound or empiric PID therapy follow based on the pregnancy test and clinical findings.
raw_b:
Conclusion: The most appropriate first step is a urine pregnancy test (urine β-hCG).

Reasoning: Any reproductive‑age woman with new pelvic/abdominal pain should have pregnancy quickly ruled out (including ectopic) because it fundamentally changes evaluation and management. A urine hCG is rapid, noninvasive, and must be known before imaging, invasive pelvic procedures, or certain treatments. After a negative/positive result you would proceed with targeted testing (wet mount/KOH/NAATs for BV/trich/candida and gonorrhea/chlamydia) and empiric treatment or pelvic ultrasound as indicated.
raw_c:
No — the most appropriate first step is a urine pregnancy test (urine hCG).

Reasoning: Any reproductive‑age patient with pelvic/abdominal pain needs pregnancy ruled out (including ectopic) before further workup or empiric therapy. A urine hCG is rapid and will guide next steps (transvaginal ultrasound and urgent care if positive, or STI testing/empiric PID treatment if negative and clinical criteria met).
raw_d:
I am sure — obtain a urine pregnancy test first.  

Ruling out pregnancy (and potential ectopic pregnancy) is the immediate, noninvasive priority in any sexually active female of reproductive age with pelvic/abdominal pain because it changes diagnostics and treatment. If the urine hCG is positive, the next step would be a transvaginal pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for intrauterine vs ectopic pregnancy; if negative, proceed with pelvic exam, vaginal swabs/microscopy and STI/PID workup and treatment as indicated.

question: A 29-year-old primigravida at 23 weeks' gestation presents to emergency care with acute left flank pain that radiates to the groin, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and increased urinary frequency. She reports no vaginal discharge. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated with regular prenatal care. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes only prenatal vitamins. She denies tobacco, alcohol, or drug use. Vital sign show: temperature 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure 114/70 mmHg, pulse 90/min, and respirations 16/min. Physical examination reveals left flank tenderness and visible blood on perineal inspection, with no abdominal guarding. Urinalysis results: - Color: Yellow - pH: 7.1 - Specific gravity: 1.010 - Blood: 3+ - Bilirubin: Negative - Glucose: Negative - Ketones: Negative - Protein: Negative - Nitrite: Negative - Leukocyte esterase: Negative - Red blood cells: Many What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Renal ultrasound B. Observation and repeat urinalysis in 24 hours C. Trial of empiric antibiotics for presumed urinary tract infection D. CT urography with contrast E. Magnetic resonance urography F. Noncontrast CT scan of abdomen and pelvis G. Cystoscopy with retrograde pyelography H. Abdominal X-ray to evaluate for nephrolithiasis I. Intravenous pyelogram J. Renal radiograph
default: Obtain a renal and pelvic ultrasound (transabdominal, with Doppler/assessment of ureteral jet) to evaluate for nephrolithiasis and hydronephrosis. Ultrasound is the preferred first‑line imaging in pregnancy; if nondiagnostic and suspicion remains high, consider MRI (or low‑dose noncontrast CT as a last resort).
alternative: Observation and repeat urinalysis in 24 hours
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: obtain a renal (renal/obstetric) ultrasound now to evaluate for nephrolithiasis and hydronephrosis.

Reasoning: acute unilateral flank pain with gross hematuria and no pyuria/positive LE suggests ureteral stone rather than UTI. In pregnancy, ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality (no ionizing radiation). Observation and repeat urinalysis alone is inadequate given the severity of pain and possibility of obstructing stone; if ultrasound is nondiagnostic and suspicion remains high, consider MRI without contrast or consult radiology/OB about low‑dose noncontrast CT.
raw_b:
Perform a renal (kidney and bladder) ultrasound as the next step.

Reasoning: Her presentation (acute flank pain radiating to groin, gross hematuria on UA, no fever or pyuria) is most consistent with urolithiasis. In pregnancy, ultrasound is the recommended initial imaging test because it is safe (no ionizing radiation) and can demonstrate hydronephrosis or a ureteral stone. If ultrasound is nondiagnostic and clinical suspicion remains high, proceed to noncontrast MR urography (or, if necessary after counseling, low‑dose CT). Provide symptomatic care (analgesia, hydration) while evaluating.
raw_c:
Yes — obtain a renal (renal/bladder) ultrasound as the next step. 

Reason: Her acute flank pain radiating to the groin with gross hematuria and no signs of infection strongly suggests ureteral stone; in pregnancy the initial imaging of choice is ultrasound (to detect hydronephrosis/stone) to avoid ionizing radiation. If ultrasound is nondiagnostic, MR urography (without contrast) is the next step rather than CT.
raw_d:
Renal (obstetric) ultrasound.

Reasoning: Acute unilateral flank pain with gross hematuria and many RBCs on urinalysis strongly suggests ureteral/renal calculi rather than cystitis (leukocyte esterase and nitrite are negative). In pregnancy you should image rather than "wait and repeat" to exclude obstructing stone/hydronephrosis that can harm mother or fetus. Ultrasound is the first‑line, radiation‑free study in pregnancy; if ultrasound is nondiagnostic and suspicion remains high, proceed to MRI without contrast or other specialist imaging.

question: A 67-year-old male patient, hospitalized 4 days ago for diverticulitis treatment, develops sudden pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. His medical history includes stable chronic kidney disease (serum creatinine 2.2 mg/dL; reference range 0.8–1.3). On examination, he is afebrile, with a blood pressure of 110/74 mm Hg, heart rate of 115 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 85% on ambient air. He is alert, oriented, and mildly dyspneic. Lung auscultation is clear bilaterally, but his left leg is swollen and tender. He is fully vaccinated against Covid-19, and SARS-CoV-2 testing is negative. A portable chest X-ray reveals no opacities or abnormalities in the heart or pleura. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
options: A. Administer supplemental oxygen and observe B. Obtain a CT angiogram of the chest C. Initiate oral anticoagulation therapy immediately D. Perform an echocardiogram to assess for right heart strain E. Perform a lower extremity Doppler ultrasound F. Obtain a ventilation-perfusion scan of the lungs G. Order a D-dimer test to rule out pulmonary embolism H. Administer thrombolytic therapy immediately without further testing I. Obtain an arterial blood gas analysis J. Administer intravenous heparin
default: Suspected pulmonary embolism with unilateral leg DVT and a normal chest x‑ray. Because his renal function is impaired (Cr 2.2 mg/dL) the next best diagnostic test is a ventilation–perfusion (V/Q) scan (preferred over CT pulmonary angiography which uses iodinated contrast). If clinical suspicion is very high and bleeding risk is acceptable, begin empiric anticoagulation (eg, IV unfractionated heparin) while arranging the V/Q scan.
raw_a:
Next best step: obtain an urgent compression (venous duplex) ultrasound of the left leg — and if it shows DVT, start therapeutic anticoagulation (use IV unfractionated heparin given his renal impairment). 

Reasoning: he has high pretest probability for PE (tachycardia, hypoxia, unilateral leg swelling). CT pulmonary angiography is less desirable with creatinine 2.2 mg/dL; a bedside compression ultrasound can rapidly confirm DVT and allow treatment without contrast. If the ultrasound is negative and clinical suspicion remains high, proceed to V/Q scan (preferred with a normal chest x‑ray) or CT as indicated. If he becomes hemodynamically unstable, start empiric IV heparin immediately.
raw_b:
Start immediate parenteral anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin (IV bolus/infusion) and arrange urgent diagnostic imaging (CT pulmonary angiography if feasible).  

Reasoning: this presentation (sudden pleuritic chest pain, hypoxemia, tachycardia, unilateral swollen/tender leg, recent hospitalization) gives a high pretest probability of acute pulmonary embolism. Guidelines call for empiric anticoagulation promptly in patients with high suspicion unless there is a contraindication. Because his creatinine is elevated, IV unfractionated heparin is preferred over immediate oral or renally cleared LMWH/DOACs (it is not renally cleared and is rapidly reversible if bleeding or procedures are needed). Obtain definitive imaging as soon as possible; if CTPA is contraindicated/unavailable, perform compression ultrasonography of the leg (and treat if positive).
raw_c:
Start immediate anticoagulation with IV unfractionated heparin and arrange diagnostic imaging (prefer V/Q scan given his renal impairment).

Reasoning: The presentation (acute pleuritic chest pain, hypoxia, tachycardia, unilateral leg swelling/tenderness, hospitalized) gives high pretest probability for PE — anticoagulation should be started promptly unless there is active bleeding. Because his creatinine is elevated (reduced GFR), unfractionated heparin is preferred (rapidly titratable and reversible, avoids LMWH/DOAC accumulation). For imaging, a V/Q scan is preferred over contrast CT pulmonary angiography here because the chest x‑ray is normal and contrast would risk worsening renal function; if V/Q is nondiagnostic or contraindicated, then weigh CT with renal-protective measures.
raw_d:
You are correct — start a therapeutic intravenous unfractionated heparin infusion immediately.

Reasoning: he has high pretest probability for acute PE (recent hospitalization, sudden pleuritic pain, hypoxemia, tachycardia, unilateral leg swelling). Empiric anticoagulation should be started promptly unless contraindicated. Because he has chronic kidney disease (Cr 2.2) and may require procedures or rapid reversal, IV unfractionated heparin is preferred over LMWH or oral DOACs. Obtain definitive imaging (CT pulmonary angiography if feasible, or V/Q scan if contrast is contraindicated) and monitor aPTT and clinical status.

question: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stage 4 chronic kidney disease reports that he completely lost vision in his right eye shortly after waking up this morning. He had no pain at the time and gradually regained his vision about one hour after the initial loss. His current blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. His vision appears normal on visual-acuity and visual-field testing. He has a normal head and neck examination without carotid bruits. He has no murmurs, and his lungs are clear to auscultation. He has a normal neurologic examination, including normal strength and sensation. Laboratory results are notable for a creatinine concentration of 3.3. mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3). He has a normal electrocardiogram. CT of the brain without contrast shows no abnormalities. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient’s vision loss?
options: A. Serum homocysteine level measurement B. Retinal fluorescein angiography C. CT angiogram of the brain D. Visual evoked potential testing E. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound F. Magnetic resonance angiogram of the brain with gadolinium G. Electroretinography H. Dilated ophthalmoscopy I. Echocardiography with bubble study J. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
default:
Carotid duplex ultrasonography of the ipsilateral carotid arteries.

Rationale: Painless, transient monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) suggests an embolic retinal ischemia source, most commonly ipsilateral carotid atherosclerotic disease. Duplex ultrasound is the noninvasive first-line test (and preferable here given his advanced CKD, which makes contrast angiography less desirable).
alternative: Magnetic resonance angiogram of the brain with gadolinium
raw_a:
Answer: Carotid duplex ultrasonography of the neck.

Reasoning: His brief, painless, unilateral vision loss is most consistent with amaurosis fugax from an ipsilateral carotid embolus — urgent evaluation for carotid stenosis is indicated. Duplex ultrasound is the noninvasive, first‑line test (no contrast, safe with CKD) and will detect hemodynamically significant carotid atherosclerosis. Gadolinium MRA (and iodinated-contrast CTA) are undesirable here because his stage 4 CKD raises risk of contrast-related complications.
raw_b:
Carotid duplex ultrasound (carotid Doppler).  

Reasoning: His painless, transient monocular vision loss is classic for amaurosis fugax from an ipsilateral carotid embolus. Duplex ultrasound is the noninvasive, first‑line test to look for carotid stenosis/plaques (absence of a bruit does not exclude significant disease). Given his chronic kidney disease, contrast studies (CTA/MRA) are less desirable initially. If carotid duplex is unrevealing, evaluate for a cardiac source (echocardiography) and perform a dilated fundoscopic/ophthalmology exam; check ESR/CRP only if giant cell arteritis is suspected.
raw_c:
Carotid duplex ultrasound.

Reason: His painless, transient monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) is most often embolic from ipsilateral carotid atherosclerosis. Duplex ultrasound is the noninvasive, first‑line test to detect carotid stenosis or plaque without iodinated or gadolinium contrast (important given his CKD). If duplex is negative, next steps would be cardiac evaluation (echo, prolonged rhythm monitoring) and consideration of inflammatory markers only if clinical suspicion for giant‑cell arteritis arises.
raw_d:
Carotid duplex ultrasound.

Reasoning: This presentation is classic amaurosis fugax from an ipsilateral carotid embolus; carotid duplex is the noninvasive, first‑line test to evaluate for carotid atherosclerotic stenosis even if no bruit is present. Contrast MRA (gadolinium) and CTA use contrast agents that are contraindicated or high‑risk in stage‑4 CKD (creatinine 3.3 mg/dL) because of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis and contrast nephropathy, respectively. If duplex is inconclusive or intervention is planned, consider noncontrast (time‑of‑flight) MRA or angiography after nephrology consultation.

question: A 2-day-old newborn is evaluated for respiratory distress and abnormal physical features. He was delivered at term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery to a 40-year-old mother with a history of epilepsy, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Her medication include metformin, phenytoin, and labetalol. She is a smoker, regularly consumes alcohol, and did not receive prenatal care. On examination, the neonate has microcephaly, hypertelorism, a flat nasal bridge, cleft palate, and a thin upper lip. Hypoplastic distal phalanges and fingernails are noted. Cardiac examination reveals a harsh continuous murmur, and lower extremity pulses are weak. Vital sign include a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate of 80/min, and oxygen saturation of 80-85% on room air. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
options: A. Chromosomal abnormality such as trisomy 21 B. Fetal alcohol syndrome C. Teratogenicity caused by maternal medication D. Maternal diabetes-related embryopathy E. Congenital rubella syndrome F. Perinatal hypoxia due to placental insufficiency G. Congenital heart defect unrelated to teratogens H. Intrauterine growth restriction due to maternal smoking I. Neonatal abstinence syndrome J. Patent ductus arteriosus
default: In utero exposure to phenytoin (maternal anticonvulsant use) — fetal hydantoin syndrome. Phenytoin causes microcephaly, cleft palate, distal phalange/nail hypoplasia and congenital cardiac defects (eg, PDA), matching this presentation.
raw_a:
Most likely cause: in utero phenytoin exposure — fetal hydantoin syndrome (maternal anticonvulsant teratogenicity).

Reasoning: the neonate’s microcephaly, cleft palate, hypoplastic distal phalanges and nails, and dysmorphic facies are classic for fetal hydantoin syndrome from maternal phenytoin. The continuous “machine‑like” murmur suggests a PDA (a possible associated cardiac defect) but the unifying etiology for the dysmorphic features is phenytoin teratogenicity rather than PDA alone.
raw_b:
Most likely cause: in utero phenytoin exposure — fetal hydantoin syndrome (phenytoin teratogenicity).

Reasoning: the combination of microcephaly, cleft palate, craniofacial anomalies and especially hypoplastic distal phalanges/fingernails is classic for fetal hydantoin syndrome; the mother’s chronic phenytoin use for epilepsy provides the exposure. Other possibilities (fetal alcohol syndrome, congenital rubella) fit some findings (thin upper lip, PDA) but do not explain the distal phalanx/nail hypoplasia as well as phenytoin does.
raw_c:
Most likely fetal hydantoin syndrome from in utero phenytoin exposure.

Reasoning: the neonate’s constellation of microcephaly, facial dysmorphism (hypertelorism, flat nasal bridge), cleft palate, hypoplastic distal phalanges and fingernails, growth/craniofacial defects and congenital heart lesion are classic for phenytoin teratogenicity. The mother’s phenytoin use during pregnancy fits this diagnosis (maternal alcohol can mimic some features but the nail/phalange hypoplasia and clefting point to hydantoin exposure).
raw_d:
Most likely cause: in utero exposure to phenytoin (fetal hydantoin syndrome).

Reasoning: the neonate’s microcephaly, cleft palate, and hypoplastic distal phalanges/nails are classic for fetal hydantoin syndrome from maternal phenytoin. A continuous “machine‑like” murmur suggests a PDA, but a PDA by itself would not explain the dysmorphic features — the unifying cause is maternal phenytoin teratogenicity.

question: A 65-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a near-syncopal episode while working in his garage. His initial vital sign show: - Temperature: 98.8°F (37.1°C) - Blood pressure: 125/62 mmHg - Pulse: 117/min - Respirations: 14/min - O2 saturation: 98% on room air Laboratory results reveal: - Hemoglobin: 7 g/dL - Hematocrit: 22% - Leukocyte count: 6,500/mm^3 with normal differential - Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3 After initiating blood products and ordering a CT scan, the patient's condition changes: - Temperature rises to 99.5°F (37.5°C) - Blood pressure drops to 87/48 mmHg - Pulse increases to 180/min - Patient develops labored breathing Which additional finding would you most likely expect in this patient?
options: A. An underlying malignancy causing anemia of chronic disease B. Sudden rupture of a vessel C. Sepsis secondary to bacterial contamination of transfused blood products D. An undiagnosed bleeding disorder such as hemophilia E. Acute hemolysis due to ABO incompatibility F. Hypocalcemia due to citrate toxicity from transfusion G. Autoimmune reaction against red blood cell antigens H. Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) I. A past medical history of repeat GI and respiratory infections J. A history of chronic kidney disease causing erythropoietin deficiency
solution_text: A past medical history of repeat GI and respiratory infections
default: New acute hypoxemic respiratory failure with bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x‑ray (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema — PaO2/FiO2 <300), consistent with transfusion‑related acute lung injury (TRALI).
alternative: A past medical history of repeat GI and respiratory infections
raw_a:
Conclusion: This is most consistent with transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI); you would expect acute hypoxemia with new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) and no signs of circulatory overload (normal BNP/PCWP). 

Reasoning: The abrupt hypotension, tachycardia, fever and respiratory distress shortly after a transfusion point to TRALI (donor anti-leukocyte antibodies causing neutrophil-mediated pulmonary capillary leak), not chronic infection history.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). You would expect acute hypoxemia with new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x‑ray (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) within hours of the transfusion, with no signs of volume overload (no JVD, normal/elevated but not markedly high BNP). 

Reason: TRALI presents within 6 hours of transfusion with fever, hypotension, tachycardia and respiratory distress; TACO typically causes hypertension and signs of volume overload, which this case lacks.
raw_c: The picture is most consistent with TRALI (transfusion‑related acute lung injury) — you would expect acute hypoxemia with new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x‑ray (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) within hours of the transfusion, with no signs of volume overload (normal BNP/PCWP).
raw_d:
Conclusion: You would most likely find an undetectable/very low serum IgA level (or a history of recurrent sinopulmonary and GI infections consistent with selective IgA deficiency).

Reasoning: The rapid onset of hypotension, bronchospasm/respiratory distress and tachycardia during transfusion is most consistent with an anaphylactic transfusion reaction caused by anti‑IgA antibodies in IgA‑deficient patients. IgA deficiency commonly presents with recurrent mucosal (respiratory and gastrointestinal) infections, and these patients can develop severe anaphylaxis to plasma-containing blood products. This presentation is distinct from TACO, which typically produces hypertension and signs of volume overload.

question: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being found unconscious on the kitchen floor by his wife, who also discovered an empty bottle of his prescription medication nearby. She notes that he has been behaving unusually since losing his job a month ago. His medical history includes essential tremor, for which he takes primidone, and he previously consumed five alcoholic drinks daily but stopped six months ago. On arrival, the patient is lethargic. His temperature is 35.2°C (95.4°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 10/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 100/59 mm Hg. He does not open his eyes, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws to painful stimuli. Pupils are 3 mm and sluggishly reactive to light. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in all extremities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Observation and supportive care only B. Intravenous fluids and naloxone C. Activated charcoal and flumazenil D. Assisted respiration and urine alkalinization E. Gastric lavage and sodium bicarbonate F. Endotracheal intubation and N-acetylcysteine G. Endotracheal intubation and intravenous naloxone H. Intravenous lipid emulsion therapy I. Hemodialysis and intravenous thiamine J. Intravenous benzodiazepines and glucose administration
default:
Secure the airway — endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.  
He has depressed consciousness with hypoventilation (GCS ≤8/high aspiration risk), so airway protection comes before charcoal or toxin-specific measures.
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation (airway protection).

Reason: he has severe CNS depression (GCS ~7) with hypoventilation and aspiration risk from likely primidone/phenobarbital overdose; airway stabilization and ventilatory support take priority. After securing the airway you can give activated charcoal if appropriate and IV sodium bicarbonate to alkalinize the urine to enhance phenobarbital elimination.
raw_b:
Immediate endotracheal intubation (airway protection/ventilatory support) — rapid-sequence intubation.

Reason: GCS = 7 (no eye opening, incomprehensible sounds, withdraws to pain) with shallow respirations → high risk of hypoventilation and aspiration, so secure the airway first. After airway control you can pursue decontamination (activated charcoal if appropriate), supportive care, and specific measures for barbiturate/primidone toxicity (e.g., enhanced elimination/alkalinization and ICU monitoring).
raw_c:
Secure the airway — endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation.

He has severe CNS and respiratory depression (GCS 7, shallow respirations) after likely primidone → phenobarbital overdose; a GCS <8 or inadequate ventilation requires immediate intubation. After the airway is secured you can administer activated charcoal (if within window) and institute enhanced elimination (urinary alkalinization ± dialysis) as indicated.
raw_d:
Endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation now — then, after airway stabilization, begin IV sodium bicarbonate to alkalinize the urine and enhance elimination of phenobarbital (primidone metabolite).

Reasoning: The patient has signs of barbiturate (primidone/phenobarbital) overdose with marked CNS depression and hypoventilation; airway/ventilatory support is the immediate priority. Urinary alkalinization is an appropriate next step to increase renal clearance of phenobarbital once the airway is secured.

question: When evaluating a patient experiencing arm pain and paresthesias, which clinical finding would most strongly suggest cervical radiculopathy rather than peripheral neuropathy?
options: A. Improvement with rest and worsening with activity B. Positive Tinel's sign at the elbow C. Nocturnal exacerbation of symptoms D. Relief of pain when holding the arm above the head E. Weakness in multiple nerve distributions F. Exacerbation with repetitive hand movements G. Reproduction of pain with tilting head to affected side and rotating head to contralateral side H. Bilateral symmetric distribution of symptoms I. Compensatory inter-phalangeal joint flexion of the thumb when attempting to pinch J. Pain localized to a specific dermatome
solution_text: Relief of pain when holding the arm above the head
default:
A positive Spurling sign — reproduction of the patient’s arm pain/paresthesias with cervical extension/rotation and axial compression — most strongly suggests cervical radiculopathy.  

(Concordant dermatomal sensory loss, focal myotomal weakness and a decreased segmental reflex [eg, biceps or triceps] would also support a root lesion over a peripheral polyneuropathy.)
alternative: Relief of pain when holding the arm above the head
raw_a:
Correct — relief of pain when the patient abducts the shoulder or places the hand on top of the head (positive Bakody/shoulder‑abduction sign) strongly suggests cervical radiculopathy.  

Reason: this maneuver reduces tension and foraminal compression of a cervical nerve root, relieving radicular symptoms; peripheral neuropathies are not typically improved by shoulder abduction. (Supportive findings would include dermatomal sensory loss, myotomal weakness, or diminished reflexes and positive Spurling’s test.)
raw_b:
Conclusion: A positive Spurling maneuver (reproduction of the patient’s radiating arm pain with neck extension/rotation and axial compression) most strongly suggests cervical radiculopathy.

Reasoning: Spurling’s test mechanically provokes compression of a cervical nerve root and is relatively specific for radiculopathy; peripheral neuropathies are not reproduced by cervical loading. Focal dermatomal sensory loss, a myotomal weakness, or reduced deep-tendon reflex in a root distribution would further support radiculopathy, whereas a bilateral symmetric stocking‑glove pattern points toward peripheral polyneuropathy.
raw_c:
A positive Spurling’s maneuver — neck extension/rotation with axial compression that reproduces the patient’s arm pain/paresthesias.

Reason: Spurling’s mechanically narrows the cervical foramina and provokes nerve‑root pain, which is characteristic of cervical radiculopathy; peripheral neuropathy is usually distal, symmetric, and not reproducible by neck movements.
raw_d: Relief of pain when holding the arm above the head (positive Bakody/shoulder abduction sign) — this suggests cervical radiculopathy because elevating the arm reduces traction/compression on a cervical nerve root; peripheral neuropathy is typically distal, symmetric, and not position-dependent.

question: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe lower chest pain radiating to the back for the past hour. The pain is associated with nausea, worsens after eating, and has led to two episodes of nonbloody vomiting. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. He consumes five to six beers daily. His current medication are enalapril and metformin. Vital sign are as follows: | Temperature | 38.5°C (101.3°F) | | --- | --- | | Blood pressure | 90/60 mm Hg | | Pulse | 110/min | On physical examination, the abdomen is distended with epigastric tenderness and guarding but no rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are decreased. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory results show a hematocrit of 48%, leukocyte count of 13,000/mm³, and a serum lipase level of 880 U/L. An ECG reveals sinus tachycardia. A tender gangliform nodule related to this patient’s condition is most likely to be palpated at which locations?
options: A. at McBurney's point B. at the 6th intercostal space on the right C. between the spinous and transverse processes of T5 and T7 on the left D. at the 5th intercostal space on the right E. between the spinous and transverse processes of T7 and T8 on the left F. at the costovertebral angle on the right G. at the 8th intercostal space on the left H. between the spinous and transverse processes of T8 and T9 on the right I. at the 7th intercostal space on the right J. at the 9th intercostal space on the right
solution_text: at the 7th intercostal space on the right
default: Pancreatic panniculitis — tender subcutaneous nodules on the lower extremities, classically the anterior shins/calf (pretibial region).
alternative: at the 7th intercostal space on the right
raw_a: Incorrect — the classic palpable, gangliform nodule associated with pancreatic (and other intra‑abdominal) malignancy is felt in the periumbilical region (Sister Mary Joseph nodule, i.e., at the umbilicus).  (Metastatic spread may also produce a left supraclavicular Virchow node.)
raw_b:
Conclusion: The classic "tender gangliform nodule" is Virchow's node — palpable in the left supraclavicular fossa (just above the left clavicle). A related metastatic nodule may also appear at the periumbilical region (Sister Mary Joseph nodule). 

Reasoning: Pancreatic (and other upper GI) malignancies metastasize to the thoracic duct drainage point producing a palpable left supraclavicular (Troisier/Virchow) node; the umbilicus is the site of the Sister Mary Joseph metastatic nodule. The 8th left intercostal space is not the correct site for these findings.
raw_c:
No — the correct site is the left supraclavicular fossa (just above the left clavicle).  

Reason: a firm, gangliform left supraclavicular node (Virchow’s node; Troisier sign) is a classic sentinel node for upper abdominal malignancies (stomach, pancreas, etc.), which is what the question is targeting.
raw_d:
I can't confirm the 7th‑right intercostal answer — that location is more consistent with gallbladder/acute cholecystitis signs. For acute pancreatitis the classic superficial findings are Cullen's sign (periumbilical ecchymosis/nodule) and Grey‑Turner's sign (flank/ecchymosis), so you would examine the periumbilical region and the flanks rather than the 7th right intercostal space. 

If you can paste the exact answer choices or clarify what is meant by “tender gangliform nodule,” I’ll pick the best option.

question: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old gravida 2, para 1 mother. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. On room air, pulse oximetry reveals an oxygen saturation of 78%. Physical examination shortly after delivery shows cyanosis, a weak cry, irregular breathing with gasping, and dysmorphic features, including a flat nose with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds, low-set ears with broad auricles, and retrognathia. The right lower limb is shorter than the left, and the right great toe is displaced. Breath sounds are diminished bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
options: A. Serum creatinine and electrolyte levels B. Skeletal survey C. Karyotyping D. Genetic microarray analysis E. Renal biopsy F. X-ray of the chest G. Chest X-ray H. Voiding cystourethrogram I. Echocardiography J. Amniotic fluid analysis
default: A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG/micturating cystourethrogram) — it will demonstrate posterior urethral valves (dilated posterior urethra/obstructing valve leaflets), the classic cause of oligohydramnios, hydronephrosis, and Potter sequence in a male neonate.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Obtain a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) to confirm posterior urethral valves.

Reasoning: A male neonate with oligohydramnios, Potter facies/limb deformities, pulmonary hypoplasia, and bilateral hydroureteronephrosis is most consistent with bladder outlet obstruction from posterior urethral valves; a VCUG directly visualizes a dilated posterior urethra and the obstructing valves. (Serum creatinine/electrolytes assess renal function but do not confirm the anatomic cause.)
raw_b:
Conclusion: Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the most appropriate test — it will confirm posterior urethral valves (PUV), the likely cause.

Reasoning: This male neonate has oligohydramnios with Potter facies, pulmonary hypoplasia (cyanosis, gasping, diminished breath sounds), limb deformities, and bilateral hydronephrosis/hydroureter on ultrasound — a classic picture of bladder outlet obstruction from PUV. A VCUG directly visualizes the urethra and bladder during voiding, demonstrating a dilated posterior urethra and the obstructing valve(s), and is the diagnostic study of choice. (Karyotype would be indicated if you primarily suspected a chromosomal syndrome, but the renal obstruction pattern points to PUV.)
raw_c:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

Reason: This male newborn has oligohydramnios with Potter facies, pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities and bilateral hydroureter/hydronephrosis — classic for bladder outlet obstruction from posterior urethral valves. A VCUG visualizes the dilated posterior urethra and obstructing valves and is the diagnostic test of choice.
raw_d:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

Reason: This male neonate has oligohydramnios, Potter facies/limb deformities, pulmonary hypoplasia, and ultrasound evidence of bilateral hydronephrosis/hydroureter — a classic picture of bladder outlet obstruction from posterior urethral valves. A VCUG directly visualizes the posterior urethra, valves, and reflux and is the diagnostic test of choice. Serum creatinine/electrolytes assess renal function but do not confirm the anatomic cause.

question: A 57-year-old male is referred to the emergency department by his primary care physician due to elevated blood pressure. During a routine health check, his blood pressure was measured at 180/115 mmHg, prompting the referral. The patient reports no symptom and states he feels well. He has a history of hypertension but no other medical condition, and his laboratory results from last week were normal. On examination, his temperature is 98.3°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 197/105 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination finding are normal. Laboratory values from this visit are as follows: Hemoglobin: 15 g/dL Hematocrit: 46% Leukocyte count: 3,400/mm³ with normal differential Platelet count: 177,000/mm³ Serum: Na⁺: 139 mEq/L Cl⁻: 102 mEq/L K⁺: 4.0 mEq/L HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L BUN: 29 mg/dL Glucose: 139 mg/dL Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL Ca²⁺: 10.2 mg/dL What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Essential hypertension with acute kidney injury B. Pheochromocytoma crisis C. Hypertensive urgency D. Primary hyperaldosteronism E. Hypertensive emergency F. Malignant hypertension G. Acute hypertensive nephrosclerosis H. Secondary hypertension due to renal artery stenosis I. Chronic kidney disease with hypertensive urgency J. Hypertension
default:
Most likely diagnosis: hypertensive emergency (accelerated/malignant hypertension) with acute kidney injury.

Reason: markedly elevated BP (≈197/105) plus new acute rise in creatinine (2.3 mg/dL vs normal last week) = evidence of acute target‑organ damage (renal), which defines a hypertensive emergency and requires urgent BP control.
alternative: Secondary hypertension due to renal artery stenosis
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: hypertensive emergency with acute kidney injury (acute hypertensive renal damage), not primary renal artery stenosis.

Reasoning: his BP is severely elevated (≈197/105) and his creatinine has acutely risen from normal last week to 2.3 mg/dL, which represents end‑organ (renal) injury—fulfilling criteria for a hypertensive emergency even though he is asymptomatic. Renal artery stenosis would more typically cause chronic or ACE‑inhibitor–precipitated rises in creatinine rather than this abrupt change. This patient needs urgent BP control in hospital (careful IV reduction, avoid overly rapid drops) and evaluation for causes of secondary HTN.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Hypertensive emergency — severe hypertension with acute end‑organ damage (acute kidney injury).

Reasoning: Although the patient feels well, his SBP is 197 mmHg and his creatinine is now 2.3 mg/dL when labs were normal last week, consistent with new acute kidney injury from severe hypertension. Presence of acute target‑organ injury (renal dysfunction) distinguishes hypertensive emergency from hypertensive urgency (which has severe BP without new end‑organ damage).
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: hypertensive emergency — specifically acute hypertensive renal injury.

Reasoning: although he has few symptoms, he has severely elevated BP with acute end-organ damage (creatinine 2.3 mg/dL vs normal labs last week → acute kidney injury). The presence of new target-organ injury (renal impairment) — not the absolute BP number or symptoms — distinguishes a hypertensive emergency from an urgency. Management: hospitalize and begin controlled IV BP reduction (eg, nicardipine or labetalol), aiming to lower MAP by ~20–25% in the first hour and more gradually thereafter; obtain urinalysis, repeat renal function, and involve nephrology.
raw_d:
Hypertensive emergency — specifically severe hypertension with acute renal injury.

Reasoning: His BP is markedly elevated (>180/120) and labs show an acute rise in creatinine (prior labs were normal last week → current Cr 2.3 mg/dL), which is objective end‑organ damage meeting criteria for a hypertensive emergency. Renal artery stenosis as the primary diagnosis is less likely here because there’s no history of ACE‑inhibitor–provoked creatinine rise, no hypokalemia, nor other chronic features suggesting RAS; the sudden deterioration in renal function points to acute hypertensive renal injury rather than chronic secondary HTN.

question: A 55-year-old woman with a history of metastatic breast cancer, ulcerative colitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for a routine follow-up visit. One year ago, she was diagnosed with stage IV, estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2–negative breast cancer with metastases to the lymph nodes, liver, and bone. She was treated with paclitaxel for 6 months, resulting in a reduction of metastatic disease, and has since been maintained on letrozole 2.5 mg daily. Additionally, she has received zoledronic acid 4 mg every 12 weeks for bone metastases. Six months ago, after years of inactive ulcerative colitis, she developed fatigue, joint pain, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, consistent with prior colitis flares. Treatment with mesalamine and rectal glucocorticoids failed, so she was started on prednisone 40 mg daily by mouth 4 months ago. Her symptom improved rapidly, and the prednisone was tapered to 5 mg daily over time. For the past 2 months, she has been stable on 5 mg daily. Attempts to reduce her prednisone further to 2.5 mg daily have resulted in significant fatigue and nausea, which resolve when the dose is increased back to 5 mg. She reports feeling well overall, with mild low back pain at the sites of her metastatic disease. Her current medication include prednisone 5 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg daily. On examination, she is afebrile with a blood pressure of 115/76 mm Hg, heart rate of 75 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Abdominal examination reveals normal bowel sounds and no tenderness. There is midline spinal tenderness at L4–L5 without vertebral step-offs. Neurologic examination shows intact cranial nerves II–XII. Skin examination reveals no hyperpigmentation. Prednisone was discontinued, and laboratory results obtained the following day are as follows: | | Patient value | Reference range | | --- | --- | --- | | Sodium (mEq/liter) | 134 | 136–145 | | Potassium (mEq/liter) | 3.8 | 3.5–5.0 | | Chloride (mEq/liter) | 100 | 98–106 | | Carbon dioxide (mEq/liter) | 24 | 21–30 | | Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL) | 15 | 10–20 | | Creatinine (mg/dL) | 0.8 | 0.6–1.1 | | Glucose (mg/dL) | 86 | 70–100 | | Magnesium (mg/dL) | 1.9 | 1.8–3.0 | | Cortisol, 8 a.m. (μg/dL) | 1.5 | 5.0–25.0 | | Adrenocorticotropic hormone (pg/mL) | 14 | 10–60 | Laboratory testing one month ago showed a normal serum sodium level. A recent CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed stable metastatic lesions in the liver, iliac crest, and lumbar spine, as well as an L5 vertebral fracture. The adrenal glands appeared normal. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Obtain 24-hour urinary free cortisol measurement B. Reassure the patient, and recommend a slower prednisone taper with an initial dose of 4 mg C. Increase prednisone dose to 7.5 mg daily and monitor symptoms D. Obtain cortisol levels 30 and 60 minutes after injection of cosyntropin E. Start hydrocortisone replacement at physiologic doses F. Obtain early morning ACTH and cortisol measurements for three consecutive days G. Schedule an endocrinology consultation for steroid-sparing therapy H. Perform CRH stimulation test I. Perform bilateral adrenal CT with contrast J. Obtain a contrast-enhanced MRI of the head (with pituitary protocol)
solution_text: Obtain a contrast-enhanced MRI of the head (with pituitary protocol)
default: This presentation is consistent with secondary (exogenous steroid–induced) adrenal suppression from chronic prednisone. Abrupt withdrawal produced low morning cortisol and inappropriately normal/low ACTH. The next step is to reinstitute glucocorticoid replacement and taper slowly — e.g., start physiologic hydrocortisone (about 15–20 mg/day in divided doses) or resume prednisone at the prior effective dose and perform a slow taper. Arrange outpatient ACTH (cosyntropin) stimulation testing later to document recovery of the HPA axis, and teach stress‑dose steroids for intercurrent illness or procedures.
alternative: Obtain a contrast-enhanced MRI of the head (with pituitary protocol)
raw_a:
Resume physiologic glucocorticoid replacement (eg, hydrocortisone ~15–20 mg/day in divided doses) and arrange endocrine follow-up — do not stop steroids abruptly; perform dynamic testing (eg, cosyntropin stimulation) later to document recovery.

Reason: Her very low 8 a.m. cortisol with an inappropriately low–normal ACTH after chronic prednisone indicates secondary (exogenous steroid–suppressed) adrenal insufficiency. Immediate physiologic replacement is indicated to relieve symptoms and prevent adrenal crisis; pituitary MRI is unnecessary unless there are other signs of pituitary disease or an alternative central cause is suspected.
raw_b:
Restart physiologic glucocorticoid replacement now — e.g., resume prednisone 5 mg daily or start oral hydrocortisone 15–20 mg/day in divided doses — and arrange endocrine follow‑up with planned dynamic testing later.

Reason: her 8 a.m. cortisol is frankly low (1.5 μg/dL) with an inappropriately low/normal ACTH, consistent with secondary (exogenous steroid–suppressed) adrenal insufficiency after chronic prednisone. Abrupt withdrawal risks adrenal crisis, so reinstitute physiologic replacement and taper with endocrinology follow‑up; perform cosyntropin (ACTH stimulation) testing later to document recovery of the HPA axis. If she were acutely hypotensive or in shock, give IV hydrocortisone immediately.
raw_c:
Restart physiologic glucocorticoid replacement (eg, hydrocortisone 15–20 mg/day in divided doses or resume prednisone 5 mg daily) and then reassess HPA recovery later with ACTH (cosyntropin) stimulation testing while you slowly taper.

Reasoning: an 8 a.m. cortisol of 1.5 μg/dL (<<3) with inappropriately low–normal ACTH after months of prednisone is diagnostic of secondary/tertiary adrenal suppression from exogenous glucocorticoids. Immediate physiologic replacement is indicated to prevent adrenal insufficiency/crisis; definitive testing (cosyntropin stimulation) can be performed after stabilization or during taper to document recovery.
raw_d:
Obtain a cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test to assess adrenal (cortisol) reserve.

Reasoning: Her low morning cortisol with inappropriately low–normal ACTH after chronic prednisone is most consistent with secondary/tertiary adrenal suppression from exogenous glucocorticoids, not metastatic pituitary disease (no headache, visual field loss, diabetes insipidus, or markedly elevated/low ACTH). A cosyntropin stimulation test will confirm adrenal insufficiency and guide replacement; pituitary MRI is not indicated initially unless testing suggests intrinsic pituitary disease or she develops focal neurologic/endocrine signs.

question: A 62-year-old female patient seeks medical attention for a 5-day history of vaginal symptom including pruritus, erythema, and thick white discharge. She is otherwise asymptomatic. Her medical history includes heart failure (ejection fraction 35%), stage 3A chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. She has no prior history of yeast infection or UTIs. Her medication regimen consists of: - Metformin 1000 mg BID - Metoprolol 50 mg daily - Lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg daily - Atorvastatin 20 mg daily - Empagliflozin 10 mg daily (initiated 8 weeks ago for HbA1c of 7.9%) Clinical examination reveals: - BP: 128/67 mm Hg - HR: 72 bpm - Temperature: 37.1°C - No suprapubic tenderness - Pelvic exam shows vulvar erythema and thick white vaginal discharge - Vaginal wet mount reveals pseudohyphae - Point-of-care urinalysis negative for bacteria and nitrites After providing appropriate treatment for the genitourinary condition, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Stop empagliflozin, and start canagliflozin B. Discontinue empagliflozin and increase metformin dose C. Add sitagliptin and discontinue empagliflozin D. Switch empagliflozin to dapagliflozin E. Continue the current medication regimen F. Reduce empagliflozin dose to 5 mg daily G. Discontinue both empagliflozin and metformin H. Stop empagliflozin and initiate insulin therapy I. Stop empagliflozin, and start dulaglutide J. Switch to a combination of metformin and sulfonylurea
default: This is vulvovaginal candidiasis (pseudohyphae). Treat (eg, fluconazole 150 mg PO single dose or topical azole), but do not stop empagliflozin for a single, treatable genital mycotic infection. The cardiovascular and renal benefits of SGLT2 inhibitors in HFrEF and CKD outweigh the risk of uncomplicated candidal vaginitis. Counsel on hygiene, treat symptoms, and monitor — consider discontinuing the SGLT2 inhibitor only if infections are recurrent or severe.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Do not stop empagliflozin routinely — treat the vulvovaginal candidiasis and continue the SGLT2 inhibitor.  

Reasoning and plan (brief):
- The clinical picture and wet mount confirm vulvovaginal candidiasis; treat with an azole (eg, fluconazole 150 mg PO once or topical azole therapy).  
- Empagliflozin commonly causes genital mycotic infections, especially soon after initiation, but these infections are usually easily treated and are not by themselves an indication to stop therapy.  
- Given this patient’s HFrEF (EF 35%) and CKD, empagliflozin provides important cardiovascular and renal benefits that generally outweigh the risk of a treatable yeast infection.  
- Only consider stopping or switching SGLT2 inhibitor if infections are severe, recurrent, or intolerable despite therapy and hygiene measures; in that case a switch to another glucose-lowering agent (eg, GLP‑1 RA) can be considered.  
- Practical note: counsel on genital hygiene, glycemic control, and recurrence prevention; monitor for adverse effects and discuss risks/benefits with the patient.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Continue the empagliflozin and treat the vulvovaginal candidiasis (eg, oral fluconazole or topical azole), with counseling about hygiene and close follow‑up — only discontinue the SGLT2 inhibitor if infections are recurrent or severe.

Reasoning: The wet mount shows candidal vaginitis, a known and usually manageable adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors. Empagliflozin provides proven morbidity/mortality and renal benefits in HFrEF and CKD, so a single, uncomplicated episode does not justify stopping it. Treat the infection, counsel the patient about genital hygiene and signs of recurrence, and reassess; consider stopping the SGLT2 inhibitor only if infections recur or are severe.
raw_c:
Conclusion: Continue empagliflozin (do not stop) after treating the vulvovaginal candidiasis; counsel and monitor, and only discontinue the SGLT2 inhibitor if infections are severe or recurrent.

Reasoning: SGLT2 inhibitors commonly cause genital mycotic infections especially in the first weeks–months, but these are usually mild and respond to topical azoles or a single oral fluconazole dose. Your patient has HFrEF (EF 35%) and CKD stage 3a — empagliflozin confers important heart‑failure and renal benefits that generally outweigh a first, manageable episode of candidiasis. Treat the infection, advise genital hygiene and follow up; consider stopping or switching agents only for recurrent or severe infections.
raw_d:
Conclusion: Do not stop empagliflozin solely for this first episode — treat the vulvovaginal candidiasis and continue the SGLT2 inhibitor.

Reasoning: The presentation and wet mount are classic for candidal vaginitis; treat with an azole (eg, topical azole or single-dose oral fluconazole 150 mg) and counsel on hygiene and glycemic control. Genital mycotic infections are a common, usually mild adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors but are not an absolute indication to discontinue therapy, especially in a patient with HFrEF (EF 35%) and CKD where empagliflozin provides proven heart‑failure and renal benefit. Only consider stopping the drug if infections are recurrent, severe, or unacceptable to the patient — and if you do stop, discuss alternative glucose therapies (eg, a GLP‑1 RA such as dulaglutide) in coordination with cardiology/endocrinology.

question: A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the clinic with several weeks of vague abdominal discomfort. She denies symptom such as dysuria, flank pain, constipation, or vaginal bleeding. Her medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension managed with lisinopril, and her surgical history includes two cesarean sections. On examination, her temperature is 98.6 ºF, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung fields without wheezes or rhonchi. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness and a positive fluid wave. Bimanual pelvic examination identifies right adnexal fullness. Which histopathologic finding in the ovary is most consistent with this clinical presentation?
options: A. Irregularly narrowed tubules with papillary branching B. Granulosa cells arranged in a Call-Exner body pattern C. Uniformly small, round cells with scant cytoplasm D. Mucin-filled glandular structures E. Spindle-shaped fibroblast bundle F. Sheets of large, pleomorphic cells with necrosis G. Signet-ring cells within glandular tissue H. Thecal cell hyperplasia I. Psammoma bodies surrounded by serous epithelium J. Lipid-laden stromal cells
default: A benign ovarian fibroma: sheets/bundles of spindle‑shaped fibroblastic cells producing abundant collagen (sex cord–stromal tumor). This fits Meigs syndrome (ovarian fibroma with ascites and right pleural effusion).
raw_a:
Conclusion: Bundles of spindle-shaped fibroblasts with abundant collagen (an ovarian fibroma).

Reasoning: The combination of a postmenopausal adnexal mass, ascites, and a right-sided pleural effusion is classic for Meigs syndrome from an ovarian fibroma. Fibromas are solid, firm tumors composed of bland spindle cells producing collagen. Mucin-filled glandular structures would indicate a mucinous (cystadenomatous/carcinomatous) tumor, which is less consistent with this triad.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Bundles of spindle-shaped fibroblasts producing abundant collagen — an ovarian fibroma (Meigs syndrome).

Reasoning: The combination of an adnexal mass, ascites, and a right-sided pleural effusion in a postmenopausal woman is classic for Meigs syndrome, caused by an ovarian fibroma. Histology of fibromas shows intersecting bundles of spindle (fibroblast-like) cells with collagen. This differs from serous epithelial neoplasms (which show papillary architecture and often psammoma bodies).
raw_c:
Conclusion: Ovarian fibroma — histology shows bundles/fascicles of spindle-shaped fibroblastic cells with abundant collagen (stromal spindle cells).

Reasoning: The combination of an ovarian mass with ascites and a right-sided pleural effusion in a postmenopausal woman is classic for Meigs syndrome, caused by an ovarian fibroma (a benign stromal tumor). This differs from epithelial ovarian carcinoma, which would show malignant epithelial cells forming papillae or gland-like structures (often with psammoma bodies in serous tumors).
raw_d:
I am confident the original answer (bundles of spindle-shaped fibroblasts) is correct. 

Reason: This patient has the classic triad of an ovarian mass, ascites, and right-sided pleural effusion—characteristic of Meigs syndrome due to an ovarian fibroma. Ovarian fibromas are solid tumors composed of spindle-shaped fibroblastic cells producing collagen. Mucin-filled glandular structures would indicate a mucinous (epithelial) tumor, which presents as a cystic, multiloculated ovarian mass rather than the solid fibroma classically associated with ascites + pleural effusion in Meigs syndrome.

question: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of low back pain that has persisted for 4 weeks. The pain worsens with forward bending and has not been adequately relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication. She reports giving birth one month ago but denies any other symptom. On physical examination, the sacral bases are found to be deep bilaterally, and the inferior lateral angles are posterior on both sides. Her range of motion in the back is limited due to pain, but the remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which additional physical exam finding are most likely in this patient?
options: A. Positive spring test with sacral sulcus asymmetry on the left B. Positive spring test and negative seated flexion test C. Negative spring test and equivocal seated flexion test D. Positive spring test and equivocal seated flexion test E. Positive spring test and positive seated flexion test on the right F. Positive spring test with bilateral sacral sulcus asymmetry G. Positive spring test and positive seated flexion test on the left H. Negative spring test and positive seated flexion test on the left I. Bilaterally positive seated flexion test with a negative spring test J. Positive spring test and positive sphinx test
solution_text: Negative spring test and equivocal seated flexion test
default: Loss of anterior sacral base motion — i.e., a negative (decreased) sacral spring test consistent with bilateral sacral extension. (You would also expect a bilaterally positive seated‑flexion test.)
alternative: Negative spring test and equivocal seated flexion test
raw_a:
Likely a positive (restricted) spring test with an equivocal/negative seated flexion test.

Reason: Bilateral deep sacral sulci and posterior inferior lateral angles are classic for a bilateral sacral extension; the extended sacral base resists anterior springing (positive spring/restricted motion), and the seated flexion is usually equivocal when both sides are equally involved.
raw_b:
Conclusion: This represents bilateral sacral extension — you would most likely find a positive (non‑springing) spring test with a negative or symmetric seated flexion test (no unilateral PSIS asymmetry).

Reasoning: Bilaterally deep sacral bases with posterior inferior lateral angles are classic for bilateral sacral extension (common postpartum). An extended sacrum resists anterior springing of the base (positive spring test), and because the dysfunction is bilateral there is no unilateral sacroiliac asymmetry to produce a one‑sided seated flexion test.
raw_c:
No — the most likely additional finding is a positive (restricted) sacral spring test consistent with bilateral sacral extension.  

Reason: Bilaterally deep sacral sulci with posterior inferior lateral angles indicate the sacral base is posterior (sacral extension); the spring test (anterior pressure on the sacral base) will be resisted/painful in extension.
raw_d:
Negative spring test and an equivocal (nonlocalizing) seated flexion test.

Reason: Bilateral posterior inferior lateral angles indicate a bilateral sacral flexion (apex posterior) pattern; flexed sacra typically do not resist anterior-directed springing (negative spring), and a bilateral dysfunction produces an equivocal/nonlocalizing seated flexion test.

question: A 51-year-old woman who engages in weightlifting comes to the clinic with recent onset back pain. She describes an aching pain rated at 6/10 that is exacerbated by heavy lifting at the gym and improves with rest. During the osteopathic structural examination, restriction is noted in T5-T10 when the patient performs toe touches and backward bending. Additionally, the left transverse process of T7 is positioned anteriorly. What is the most likely somatic dysfunction diagnosis for the T5-T10 region?
options: A. ERRSL B. FSLRR C. FSRRL D. ESRRL E. NSRRL F. ESLRR G. FRRSL H. NRRSL I. NSLRR J. FSLLR
default:
A Type I (neutral) group somatic dysfunction of T5–T10, sidebent left and rotated right. 

Rationale: restriction of the group in both flexion (toe touch) and extension (backward bending) indicates a neutral (Type I) group dysfunction; an anterior left T7 transverse process implies rotation to the right, so the group is sidebent left and rotated right.
raw_a:
No — the correct diagnosis is a Type I (neutral) group dysfunction of T5–T10: sidebent left and rotated right (neutral, SB L, R R).

Reasoning: restriction with both forward (toe touch) and backward bending indicates a neutral (Type I) group dysfunction. An anterior left T7 transverse process indicates rotation to the right, and in Type I groups sidebending and rotation occur to opposite sides, so the group is sidebent left and rotated right.
raw_b:
Diagnosis: Type I (neutral) somatic dysfunction of T5–T10 — NSLRR (neutral, sidebent left, rotated right).

Reasoning: The restriction is present with both flexion (toe touches) and extension (backward bending), which indicates a neutral/group (Type I) dysfunction. The left T7 transverse process is anterior, which corresponds to rotation to the right (the TP on the side opposite the rotation becomes anterior). In Type I dysfunction rotation and sidebending are to opposite sides, so right rotation implies left sidebending → NSLRR.
raw_c:
Neutral somatic dysfunction of T5–T10: sidebent left and rotated right (N SLRR).

Reason: a group (T5–T10) implies a Type I (neutral) dysfunction. An anterior left T7 transverse process indicates rotation to the right (the TP on the side of rotation is posterior), and in Type I lesions rotation and sidebending are opposite → sidebent left. Restriction in both forward (toe touches) and backward bending supports a neutral/group dysfunction rather than a single flexed/extended (Type II) lesion.
raw_d:
Type I (neutral) group dysfunction of T5–T10: sidebent left, rotated right (N S L R R).

Reason: the region is restricted in both forward flexion (toe touches) and extension → neutral/group (Type I).
