Reason: pneumobilia + dilated small-bowel loops in an elderly patient with chronic cholelithiasis is classic for gallstone ileus (Rigler’s triad: pneumobilia, SBO, ectopic/often calcified gallstone), with obstruction typically at the terminal ileum/ileocecal region.

question: A male patient aged 55 comes to the office for a routine examination. He describes experiencing occasional headaches and frequent falls in recent months, which he attributes to difficulty seeing objects in his peripheral vision. He also mentions erectile dysfunction with his new partner. His medical history includes reduced ejection fraction heart failure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and peripheral arterial disease. He underwent bilateral cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation two years ago. His vital sign show: temperature 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and blood pressure 145/80 mmHg. Fundoscopic examination reveals optic disc rim thinning and asymmetrical cup/disc ratios between both eyes. The neurological examination is otherwise normal. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?
options: A. Laser trabeculoplasty B. Topical latanoprost C. Topical pilocarpine D. Topical apraclonidine E. Intravenous acetazolamide F. Oral brimonidine G. Topical atropine H. Topical dorzolamide I. Topical timolol J. Oral methazolamide
default: Findings are most consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma. The best next step is to begin a topical prostaglandin analogue (eg, latanoprost) to lower intraocular pressure. (Topical β‑blockers are relatively contraindicated here because of his COPD and cardiac disease.)
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: start a topical prostaglandin analog (eg, latanoprost) to lower intraocular pressure.

Reasoning: The history of progressive peripheral vision loss with asymmetric optic-disc cupping is classic for open‑angle glaucoma. First‑line medical therapy is a prostaglandin analog to reduce IOP. Topical β‑blockers (eg, timolol) — often used — are relatively contraindicated here because his reduced ejection‑fraction heart failure and COPD risk systemic bronchospasm and cardiac effects. Apraclonidine is a short‑acting α‑agonist used for acute lowering or diagnostic testing, not the preferred long‑term first‑line therapy. Arrange ophthalmology follow‑up for IOP measurement and ongoing management.
raw_b:
Most appropriate next step: obtain MRI of the brain with pituitary protocol (and check serum prolactin).

Reasoning: Headache + progressive peripheral vision loss (likely bitemporal hemianopsia) + new-onset erectile dysfunction strongly suggest a sellar mass (eg, pituitary macroadenoma) compressing the optic chiasm and causing hypogonadism. Treating for glaucoma (eg, starting latanoprost) risks missing a surgical/medical intracranial lesion — so image the sella and obtain endocrine testing (prolactin, other pituitary hormones) and formal visual field testing before instituting ocular hypotensive therapy.
raw_c:
Start a topical prostaglandin analog (eg, latanoprost) and arrange IOP measurement and formal visual field testing.

Reasoning: The asymmetric optic‑disc cupping with peripheral visual field loss is most consistent with chronic open‑angle glaucoma. First‑line medical therapy is a prostaglandin analog to lower IOP. Avoid topical β‑blockers (eg, timolol) in this patient because his COPD and heart‑failure history increase risk of bronchospasm and cardiac adverse effects; also obtain tonometry and automated perimetry and prompt ophthalmology follow‑up.
raw_d:
Topical latanoprost.

This picture fits chronic open‑angle glaucoma (peripheral field loss, asymmetric optic disc cupping). First‑line medical therapy is a prostaglandin analog (eg, latanoprost) — once‑daily, effective IOP lowering with minimal systemic effects and no contraindication given his COPD/heart‑failure. Apraclonidine is an alpha‑2 agonist used short‑term (eg, peri‑operative IOP spikes) and shows tachyphylaxis, so it is not appropriate as chronic initial therapy. Beta‑blocker drops would also be undesirable given his COPD and reduced EF.

question: A 20-year-old male presents to the clinic six weeks after undergoing abdominal surgery for a gunshot wound, reporting diffuse, achy abdominal pain rated as 4/10. He has been compliant with wound care and denies additional symptom. He has no significant past medical history and is not taking any medication. Vital sign are normal. Physical examination reveals a nearly healed surgical incision in the left upper quadrant without surrounding erythema or edema. Structural examination identifies a hypertonic rectus abdominis muscle that is tender to palpation. An anterior-superior iliac spine (ASIS) compression test is asymmetric, with the right ASIS inferior when supine and the left posterior-superior iliac spine (PSIS) inferior when prone. The pubic symphysis is tender, with asymmetry of the pubic tubercles and a taut, tender left inguinal ligament. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Left posterior innominate rotation B. Left superior pubic shear C. Bilateral pubic compression D. Right anterior innominate rotation E. Right posterior innominate rotation F. Left inferior pubic shear G. Sacral torsion on a left oblique axis H. Right superior pubic shear I. Right inferior innominate shear J. Pubic symphysis compression
default:
Pelvic ring dysfunction — specifically a pelvic torsion with a right anterior innominate and left posterior innominate rotation with an associated pubic symphysis shear (pubic dysfunction). 

Rationale: right ASIS inferior (anteriorly rotated innominate) and left PSIS inferior when prone (posteriorly rotated innominate) with pubic tubercle asymmetry, pubic tenderness and rectus hypertonicity point to innominate rotation with pubic shear.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: left superior pubic shear.

Reasoning: The pubic tubercle asymmetry with a tender pubic symphysis and a taut, tender left inguinal ligament (attachment at the pubic tubercle) points to the left pubic bone being displaced superiorly. Hypertonicity/tenderness of the rectus abdominis (origin at the pubis) supports this. The asymmetric ASIS/PSIS findings on positional testing are consistent with compensatory innominate rotation and a pubic shear on the left.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Left posterior innominate (left posteriorly rotated ilium), not a primary right superior pubic shear.

Reasoning: Supine the right ASIS is lower (so the left ASIS is relatively higher), and prone the left PSIS is lower — the pattern (ASIS high/PSIS low on the same side) is diagnostic of a posteriorly rotated innominate on the left. The tender pubic symphysis and taut left inguinal ligament are consistent secondary findings from that left posterior innominate rather than an isolated right superior pubic shear.
raw_c:
Right anterior innominate rotation (right anterior pelvic torsion).

Reasoning: Supine ASIS asymmetry with the right ASIS inferior indicates a right anteriorly rotated innominate; prone PSIS asymmetry with the left PSIS inferior indicates the contralateral posterior rotation — the classic paired pattern of a right anterior / left posterior innominate torsion. Pubic tubercle asymmetry, pubic tenderness and a taut inguinal ligament are consistent with the resultant pelvic ring malposition.
raw_d:
Left superior pubic shear.

Reasoning: the taut, tender left inguinal ligament and asymmetric pubic tubercles indicate the left pubic bone is displaced superiorly. The hypertonic, tender rectus abdominis (which inserts on the pubic crest) and the pattern of ASIS/PSIS asymmetry are consistent with a compensatory innominate/pelvic torsion accompanying a left superior pubic shear.

question: A 7-year-old male child presents to the clinic with a three-day history of symptom including left facial swelling, pain in the cheek area, and mild fever. He shows sign of dysphagia with saliva pooling and has difficulty with mouth opening. The patient reports having experienced similar episodes three times previously, with each episode resolving within a week. He denies experiencing joint pain, muscle aches, or ocular dryness. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.2°C and heart rate of 108 beats per minute, with other vital sign being normal. There is notable swelling anterior to the left ear that extends downward and backward, making the mandibular angle difficult to visualize. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
options: A. Perform serologic studies for mumps B. Order sialography C. Test for Sjögren's antibodies D. Start empiric antibiotics E. Order HIV testing F. Biopsy the parotid gland G. Recommend pain control H. Perform fine needle aspiration I. Order immediate CT scan with contrast J. Perform ultrasound imaging
default:
Obtain a focused ultrasound of the left parotid gland. 

Rationale: recurrent, unilateral painful parotid swelling suggests obstructive sialadenitis/sialolithiasis (or focal abscess). Ultrasound is the noninvasive first-line test to look for stones, ductal dilation, or abscess and will guide management (conservative measures/sialogogues and antibiotics vs ENT referral for sialendoscopy or drainage).
raw_a:
No — the most appropriate next step is to obtain imaging (ultrasound of the parotid/neck) to evaluate for an obstructing sialolith or abscess rather than only recommending analgesia.

Reasoning: recurrent unilateral painful parotid swelling in a child suggests juvenile recurrent parotitis or obstructive sialadenitis; the current dysphagia, salivary pooling and trismus raise concern for duct obstruction or focal collection. Ultrasound is the noninvasive first-line study to detect stones, ductal dilation or abscess and will guide whether conservative care (hydration, sialogogues, massage, analgesics ± oral antibiotics) is appropriate or whether ENT evaluation, IV antibiotics and drainage/CT are needed if an abscess or deep-space infection is present.
raw_b:
Most appropriate next step: manage conservatively now — warm compresses, gland massage/sialogogues (lemon drops), good hydration, analgesia/antipyretic, and inspect/Stensen’s duct for purulent discharge (culture and start antibiotics only if purulence or systemic bacterial infection is present).

Reasoning: This child’s history of recurrent, self‑limited unilateral parotid swelling is classic for juvenile recurrent parotitis. Routine ultrasound is not required as the immediate next step unless you suspect an obstructing stone, abscess, tumor, or need imaging after failed conservative therapy. Acute management is supportive; antibiotics are reserved for documented bacterial infection.
raw_c:
Start empiric antibiotics directed at Staphylococcus aureus (eg, oral dicloxacillin or amoxicillin–clavulanate) plus supportive care (hydration, warm compresses, sialogogues and gland massage). 

Reasoning: This presentation is most consistent with acute bacterial parotitis (unilateral parotid swelling, trismus/dysphagia, pooling of saliva) in a child with recurrent episodes. Initial management is empiric anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics and supportive measures; ultrasound is reserved if there is poor response, concern for abscess, or to evaluate for a stone/structural lesion.
raw_d:
No — obtain an ultrasound of the parotid region next.

Reasoning: recurrent episodes plus current dysphagia, pooling of saliva and trismus raise concern for obstructive sialadenitis or a drainable abscess. Ultrasound is quick, noninvasive, and will detect sialoliths or collections and guide whether urgent drainage, CT/ENT evaluation, or empiric antibiotics are needed. Analgesia, hydration and sialogogues may be given while imaging is arranged, but imaging should be obtained before deciding definitive therapy.

question: A full-term newborn girl, delivered vaginally at 38 weeks of gestation to a healthy 27-year-old mother, develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios noted on prenatal ultrasound. Group B Streptococcus (GBS) screening was negative, and membranes ruptured 2 hours prior to delivery with clear amniotic fluid. The delivery was otherwise uncomplicated. In the NICU, the newborn exhibits tachypnea, grunting, and mucous bubbling from the nose and mouth. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate is 145 beats/min, respiratory rate is 68/min, and SpO2 is 90% on 40% FiO2. An orogastric tube curls back upon insertion. Based on the most likely cause of her respiratory distress, which physical examination finding would be expected?
options: A. Absent thumb B. Webbed neck C. Scaphoid abdomen D. Micrognathia E. Cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen therapy F. Bounding peripheral pulses G. Single umbilical artery H. Focal crackles on lung examination I. Meconium stained skin J. Rocker-bottom feet
default: A distended, tympanitic abdomen from air passing into the stomach through a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (most common TEF associated with esophageal atresia).
raw_a:
Expected finding: a distended, tympanitic abdomen (air-filled stomach/intestines).

Reasoning: the clinical picture (polyhydramnios, inability to pass an orogastric tube, respiratory distress) most likely reflects esophageal atresia with a distal tracheoesophageal fistula. Air from the trachea enters the GI tract via the fistula, producing abdominal distension; absent thumb is unrelated.
raw_b:
Expected finding: a distended, gas-filled (scaphoid absent) abdomen from air entering the stomach through a distal tracheoesophageal fistula.

Reasoning: polyhydramnios + an orogastric tube that coils in the upper pouch strongly suggests esophageal atresia with a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (the common type). Air from the trachea passes into the distal esophagus/stomach, producing abdominal distension and bowel gas on x‑ray. Micrognathia is seen in Pierre Robin sequence and would not explain the coiled NG/OG tube or polyhydramnios.
raw_c:
No — the expected finding is a distended, tympanitic abdomen. 

Reason: the presentation (polyhydramnios, OG tube coiling) indicates esophageal atresia with a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (the common type). Air from the trachea passes into the stomach via the fistula, producing gastric/abdominal distention and respiratory symptoms from aspiration.
raw_d:
No — the more likely expected finding is abdominal distention (an air-filled, distended stomach). 

Reasoning: The curled orogastric tube and polyhydramnios point to esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula (the common type). Air from the trachea passes into the stomach via the distal fistula producing abdominal distension. An absent thumb can occur as part of VACTERL associations with TEF but is not the immediate, characteristic exam finding.

question: A 32-year-old male seeks medical attention from his primary care provider due to a widespread rash. He reports having had a non-painful lesion on his penile glans approximately 6 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. The patient discloses sexual activity with both male and female partners and infrequent condom use. Current physical examination reveals no active lesions on his genitalia or elsewhere, but demonstrates a maculopapular rash affecting his palms and soles. Which diagnostic test would be most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
options: A. Blood culture for Treponema pallidum B. Darkfield microscopy C. Gram stain of the rash exudate D. Nucleic acid amplification E. Western blot for Treponema pallidum F. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for Treponema pallidum G. Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test H. Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test I. Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for Treponema pallidum J. Skin biopsy of the rash
default: Order serologic testing for syphilis: start with a non‑treponemal test (RPR or VDRL) and confirm a positive result with a treponemal-specific test (eg, FTA‑ABS or TP‑PA).
raw_a:
Yes — the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA‑ABS) test is an appropriate confirmatory test. 

Reasoning: the history (painless chancre that resolved and subsequent maculopapular rash including palms/soles) is classic for secondary syphilis. Standard approach is to screen with a non‑treponemal test (RPR or VDRL) and confirm a positive result with a treponemal test such as FTA‑ABS (or TPPA), which is highly specific for Treponema pallidum.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Confirm with a treponemal-specific test — e.g., FTA-ABS (or TP-PA).

Reasoning: The presentation is classic secondary syphilis. Non-treponemal tests (RPR/VDRL) are used for screening and for monitoring treatment response, but a positive treponemal-specific assay (FTA-ABS or TP-PA) is the standard confirmatory test. (Modern labs often use treponemal EIAs for initial screening in a “reverse” algorithm, but confirmation is still with a specific treponemal test such as FTA-ABS/TP-PA.)
raw_c:
No — the most appropriate initial test is a non-treponemal test such as the rapid plasma reagin (RPR) (with a positive result confirmed by a treponemal-specific test like TP-PA or FTA‑ABS).  

Reason: the presentation fits secondary syphilis, when RPR/VDRL are highly sensitive and used for screening and titers; treponemal tests are used to confirm.
raw_d:
Correct — Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA‑ABS) is the best confirmatory test. 

Reason: the history and palmar/plantar maculopapular rash strongly suggest secondary syphilis. Non‑treponemal tests (RPR/VDRL) are used for screening and treatment monitoring, but confirmation requires a treponemal‑specific assay such as FTA‑ABS (or TP‑PA); modern labs may also use treponemal EIAs for similar confirmation.

question: A 24-year-old breastfeeding woman visits her primary care physician due to severe unilateral breast pain that has progressively worsened, making it difficult for her to breastfeed from her left breast. Her medical history includes gestational diabetes managed with diet and exercise. Vital sign reveal a temperature of 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure of 137/69 mmHg, pulse of 100/min, respirations of 13/min, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination shows an erythematous left breast with a 3-cm tender and fluctuant mass. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
options: A. Warm compresses and observation B. Ice packs and breast pumping C. Oral antibiotics and continued breastfeeding D. Core needle biopsy to confirm abscess E. Incision and drainage F. Surgical excision of the mass G. Needle biopsy to rule out inflammatory breast cancer H. Ultrasound and fine needle aspiration I. Vancomycin and discharge home J. Mammography to evaluate for malignancy
default: This presentation is lactational mastitis with a breast abscess. The next step is ultrasound-guided needle aspiration of the abscess (obtain fluid for culture) and start empiric anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics (eg, dicloxacillin or cephalexin; use clindamycin/TMP‑SMX if MRSA likely). Continue frequent breastfeeding or pumping to empty the breast.
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: ultrasound-guided needle aspiration of the abscess, start oral anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics, and continue breastfeeding/pumping.

Reasoning: This presentation is a lactational breast abscess — fluctuant 3‑cm collection with fever. Needle aspiration (often ultrasound guided) relieves the collection, preserves breastfeeding, and allows culture; incision-and-drainage is reserved for very large or refractory abscesses. Outpatient oral antibiotics that cover Staphylococcus aureus (eg, dicloxacillin or cephalexin for MSSA; clindamycin or TMP‑SMX if MRSA concern) are appropriate. IV vancomycin is unnecessary unless there is severe systemic illness, inpatient care, or proven/strongly suspected invasive MRSA.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Perform ultrasound-guided percutaneous needle aspiration of the abscess (with culture) and start empiric anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics while encouraging continued breastfeeding/pumping.

Reasoning: This presentation is a lactational breast abscess. For abscesses ≤ ~5 cm, ultrasound-guided aspiration is the preferred initial drainage method (less invasive, effective, allows continued breastfeeding). Start empiric therapy directed at S. aureus (e.g., dicloxacillin or cephalexin; clindamycin or TMP‑SMX if MRSA is a concern). Incision-and-drainage is reserved for very large, multiloculated, or refractory abscesses.
raw_c:
Perform ultrasound-guided needle aspiration (drainage) of the suspected breast abscess and start empiric anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics (eg, dicloxacillin/cephalexin; clindamycin if MRSA risk); continue breastfeeding/pumping.

Reason: The fever, erythema and a 3‑cm fluctuant mass indicate a lactational abscess that requires drainage. Ultrasound confirms the collection and guides needle aspiration, which is preferred initially to relieve the abscess and preserve breastfeeding; I&D is reserved for large, multiloculated, or refractory abscesses.
raw_d:
No — the best next step is ultrasound-guided drainage (needle aspiration or I&D as indicated) of the presumed breast abscess plus appropriate oral antibiotics and continuation of breastfeeding, not IV vancomycin with discharge.

Reasoning: a fluctuant 3‑cm, tender, erythematous lesion in a lactating woman is most consistent with a breast abscess, which requires drainage (ultrasound confirms/locates and guides aspiration or I&D). Antibiotics should cover Staph aureus (dicloxacillin or cephalexin for likely MSSA; clindamycin or TMP‑SMX if MRSA is suspected). IV vancomycin is reserved for severe inpatient MRSA infections and is not appropriate as routine outpatient therapy.

question: The following data were recorded for a patient with isolated aortic regurgitation: transmitral flow of 80 cc/beat, flow across the aortic valve of 140 cc/beat, and a TVI of the aortic regurgitation signal measuring 100 cm. Which best characterizes the severity of the patient's aortic regurgitation?
options: A. Mild B. Non-significant C. Hemodynamically insignificant D. Borderline severe E. Moderate F. Mild-to-moderate G. Trace H. Physiologic I. Moderate-to-severe J. Severe
default:
Regurgitant volume = 140 − 80 = 60 mL.  
EROA = regurgitant volume / VTIAR = 60 mL / 100 cm = 0.6 cm² (60 mm²).  

This corresponds to severe aortic regurgitation.
raw_a:
Moderate-to-severe (borderline severe).

Reason: regurgitant volume = aortic forward − transmitral = 140 − 80 = 60 mL. That meets the volume threshold often used for severe AR (≈60 mL), but the regurgitant fraction = 60/140 ≈ 43% (below the ≥50% cutoff for severe), placing it in the moderate-to-severe range. The long AR TVI (100 cm) further supports significant regurgitation.
raw_b:
Answer: Moderate aortic regurgitation (not severe).

Reasoning: Regurgitant volume = aortic flow − transmitral flow = 140 − 80 = 60 mL. Regurgitant fraction = 60 / 140 = 0.43 (43%). Severe AR is usually defined as RF ≥50% (or RV ≥60–65 mL with corroborating findings); an RF ≈43% falls in the moderate (moderate–severe borderline) range.
raw_c:
Conclusion: Severe aortic regurgitation.

Reasoning: Regurgitant volume = aortic flow − transmitral flow = 140 − 80 = 60 mL. ERO = RV / VTIAR = 60 mL / 100 cm = 0.6 cm² (1 cm³ = 1 mL so units work out). RV ≥60 mL and ERO ≥0.30 cm² meet guideline criteria for severe AR. (Regurgitant fraction = 60/140 ≈ 43% is borderline, but the RV and ERO classify this as severe.)
raw_d:
Moderate-to-severe (borderline severe).

Reason: regurgitant volume = aortic flow − transmitral flow = 140 − 80 = 60 mL/beat. Regurgitant fraction = 60/140 ≈ 43%. Many criteria use RV ≥60 mL as the cutoff for severe but RF ≥50% for severe; here RV meets the severe threshold while RF falls in the moderate range, so the correct characterization is intermediate — moderate-to-severe (borderline severe).

question: Improper superior positioning of the baseplate during reverse shoulder arthroplasty is associated with an increased risk of which complications?
options: A. Superior scapular notching B. Medial glenoid wear C. Glenoid component loosening D. Excessive deltoid tension E. Increased risk of rotator cuff tear F. Increased risk of acromial fracture G. Inferior acromial erosion H. Posterior glenoid subluxation I. Inferior scapular notching J. Superior humeral migration
default: Superior placement of the baseplate increases the risk of scapular notching — with consequent glenoid/baseplate loosening and wear — and is also associated with higher rates of instability/dislocation.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Superior positioning of the baseplate increases the risk of inferior scapular notching — and secondarily leads to increased polyethylene wear, eccentric loading with baseplate loosening/early implant failure, decreased ROM/impingement, and higher rates of instability (and potentially scapular spine stress fractures).

Reasoning: Placing the baseplate too superiorly shifts the glenosphere upward, promotes humeral-cup impingement on the inferior scapular neck (notching), creates eccentric forces on the baseplate and bearing surfaces, and alters deltoid/soft‑tissue mechanics, all of which produce the above complications.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Superior malpositioning of the glenoid baseplate in reverse shoulder arthroplasty most classically increases scapular notching and the sequelae of eccentric loading — i.e., accelerated polyethylene wear and glenoid baseplate loosening — and it also raises the risk of impingement-related loss of motion, instability and increased deltoid/acromial stress (acromial/scapular‑spine fractures).

Brief reasoning: Placing the baseplate too superiorly moves the center of rotation cephalad so the humeral cup impinges on the scapular neck, producing mechanical abrasion (scapular notching), eccentric forces on the baseplate (loosening) and altered deltoid mechanics (instability and acromial stress). It is not primarily associated with causing native rotator‑cuff tears.
raw_c:
No — superior positioning of the glenoid baseplate increases the risk of scapular notching (with associated polyethylene wear) and glenoid/baseplate loosening/failure; it also increases impingement and instability. 

Reason: a superiorly placed/tilted baseplate causes the humeral component to impinge on the scapular neck, producing notching and increased shear forces on the baseplate that promote micromotion and loosening.
raw_d:
Correct: superior placement of the glenoid baseplate increases the risk of inferior scapular notching.  

Reason: a superiorly positioned baseplate (or insufficient inferiorization/inferior tilt) brings the glenosphere closer to the scapular neck, promoting impingement of the humeral cup on the inferior scapular neck during adduction and leading to polyethylene wear and inferior scapular notching.

question: Which intraoperative test for diagnosing acute syndesmotic injury of the ankle demonstrates the lowest rate of false-positive results and minimal inter-observer variability?
options: A. Fibular translation B. Hook test C. Talar tilt test D. External rotation stress test E. Reverse external rotation stress test F. Posterior drawer test G. Thompson test H. Anterior drawer test I. Fibular translation test J. Cotton test
default: Diagnostic ankle arthroscopy (direct visualization and probing of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis). It has the lowest false‑positive rate and the least inter‑observer variability among intraoperative tests.
raw_a:
Conclusion: The hook (lateral fibular translation/Cotton) test. 

Reasoning: The hook test applies a direct lateral traction to the distal fibula under direct visualization/fluoroscopy, giving an objective measurement of diastasis. Clinical and biomechanical studies report lower false‑positive rates and superior inter‑observer agreement compared with the external‑rotation stress test, which is more technique‑dependent and prone to examiner and positioning variability.
raw_b:
Conclusion: The fibular "hook" test (hook test) — it has the lowest false‑positive rate and the best inter‑observer reproducibility for intraoperative assessment of syndesmotic instability.

Reasoning: Unlike the anterior drawer (which assesses ATFL laxity), the hook test applies a standardized lateral translation force to the distal fibula under fluoroscopy and directly demonstrates syndesmotic diastasis. Published series comparing intraoperative maneuvers report the hook test as highly specific, reproducible between observers, and less prone to false positives than stress or translation tests that rely on rotation or subjective radiographic measurements.
raw_c:
Conclusion: The hook (Cotton) test.  

Reasoning: The intraoperative “hook” or Cotton test—direct lateral translation of the distal fibula (often under fluoroscopy)—directly stresses the syndesmosis, gives an objective radiographic measure of diastasis, and has been shown to have a lower false‑positive rate and less inter‑observer variability than stress tests such as the external rotation test or the anterior drawer (which assesses the ATFL, not the syndesmosis).
raw_d:
External rotation stress test. 

Reason: When performed intraoperatively (under anesthesia with a standardized external rotation torque and fluoroscopic assessment), the external rotation stress test most directly stresses the syndesmosis, yields the highest specificity (lowest false-positive rate) among commonly used tests, and has shown good inter‑observer agreement in comparative studies.

question: A 50-year-old woman with diabetes reports experiencing pain and tingling in her left arm, specifically on the ulnar side of her hand and wrist. She denies any weakness or difficulty with fine motor skills. Her symptom worsen when she sleeps on her left side without a pillow and with her left elbow extended, but improve when she sleeps with her left hand elevated above her head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Myofascial pain syndrome B. Peripheral neuropathy due to diabetes C. Radial nerve compression D. Median nerve entrapment at the wrist E. Guyon’s canal syndrome F. Brachial plexopathy G. Cervical radiculopathy H. Ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow I. Cubital tunnel syndrome J. Carpal tunnel syndrome
default:
Most likely ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome). 

Rationale: paresthesias confined to the ulnar distribution, nocturnal worsening with pressure on the medial elbow (sleeping on that side without a pillow) and improvement with repositioning, with diabetes as a risk factor for focal neuropathies. Early sensory-only symptoms are common before weakness appears.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: ulnar nerve entrapment (ulnar neuropathy), most likely at the elbow (cubital tunnel).

Reasoning: her symptoms are strictly in the ulnar distribution (ulnar side of hand/wrist), are positional and worse with side‑sleeping/pressure on the medial elbow, and improve with elevation (reducing local compression/venous congestion). There is no neck pain or objective motor loss to suggest a cervical C8/T1 radiculopathy.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: ulnar nerve compression at the wrist (Guyon’s canal) from positional pressure while sleeping.

Reasoning: her symptoms are limited to the ulnar distribution of the hand and are purely sensory, and they are provoked by a sleeping posture that would compress the hypothenar/wrist area (sleeping on the side without pillow) and relieved by elevating the hand (removing pressure). Cubital tunnel syndrome at the elbow would typically worsen with elbow flexion and stretch of the nerve, not with elbow extension, so that finding argues against an elbow entrapment. Diabetes increases risk of focal entrapments. You can confirm with local Tinel’s test at Guyon’s canal and, if needed, nerve conduction studies/EMG.
raw_c:
Most likely: ulnar nerve compression at the wrist (Guyon’s canal) from positional/external pressure.

Reasoning: the symptoms are strictly ulnar-sided sensory symptoms that worsen with a sleep position that likely presses the ulnar side of the wrist/hand and improve when the hand is elevated. Cubital tunnel (elbow) entrapment is typically provoked by elbow flexion, whereas your history describes worsening with elbow extended. Diabetes also predisposes to focal mononeuropathies from compression.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: Ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome).

Reasoning: Her paresthesias are strictly in the ulnar distribution (ulnar side of hand/wrist), are provoked by an elbow/arm sleeping position (consistent with direct compression/tension at the elbow), and there is no neck pain, proximal radicular signs, or motor weakness to suggest a cervical root lesion. Diabetes predisposes to focal mononeuropathies, and avoidance of elbow pressure/positioning relieving symptoms favors a peripheral ulnar neuropathy over cervical radiculopathy.

question: A 70-year-old female presents to the emergency department via ambulance following a syncopal episode, with a 24-hour history of bright red rectal bleeding. Her initial vital sign show temperature 99.4°F, blood pressure 80/48 mmHg, heart rate 130/minute, respiratory rate 22/minute, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. She received a 1-liter normal saline bolus during transport, resulting in blood pressure 95/50 mmHg and heart rate 120/minute, followed by another liter in the ED. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, with no prior colonoscopies. On examination, she appears pale and ill but has no abdominal tenderness. Rectal exam reveals bright red blood, and hemoglobin is 8.5. Her blood pressure improves with IV fluid resuscitation. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic study?
options: A. Upper endoscopy B. Flexible sigmoidoscopy C. CT angiography D. CT of the abdomen and pelvis E. Capsule endoscopy F. Double-balloon enteroscopy G. Colonoscopy H. Push enteroscopy I. Tagged red blood cell scan J. Mesenteric angiography
default:
Urgent mesenteric (catheter) angiography.

Rationale: she has brisk hematochezia with recent hemodynamic instability. Angiography can rapidly localize bleeding at rates ≥~0.5 mL/min and allows therapeutic embolization. Colonoscopy requires bowel prep and is less useful in active, severe bleeding; a tagged RBC scan is slower and less useful for immediate therapy.
raw_a:
Most appropriate next diagnostic study: urgent colonoscopy (after rapid bowel preparation) — not capsule endoscopy.

Reasoning: She has acute hematochezia with hemodynamic improvement after resuscitation. Urgent colonoscopy is the preferred initial diagnostic and potentially therapeutic test for acute lower GI bleeding. Capsule endoscopy is used for suspected small‑bowel/occult bleeding when endoscopy is non‑diagnostic, and angiography is reserved for ongoing massive bleeding that precludes adequate colonoscopic visualization.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Mesenteric angiography (conventional mesenteric arteriography with possible embolization) is the most appropriate next diagnostic study.

Reasoning: She has an acute, possibly brisk lower GI bleed with initial hemodynamic instability that only partially stabilized with fluids. Angiography can rapidly localize active bleeding and provide therapeutic embolization if needed (sensitivity at higher bleed rates ≈0.5 mL/min). A tagged RBC scan is useful for intermittent/slow bleeding in clinically stable patients but is slower, less useful in an unstable or brisk bleed, and is not therapeutic. (If a noninvasive first step is preferred and the patient is stable enough, CT angiography can be used to localize bleeding prior to catheter angiography.)
raw_c:
No — the best next study is urgent mesenteric (selective mesenteric) angiography with possible embolization.

Reasoning: She is hemodynamically unstable with ongoing bright-red bleeding and cannot undergo an immediate colonoscopy (requires bowel prep and relative stability). Tagged RBC scans are slow and better for intermittent, low-rate bleeds. Angiography rapidly localizes brisk bleeding and allows therapeutic embolization, making it the appropriate next step.
raw_d:
No — the most appropriate next diagnostic study is a contrast-enhanced CT angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis.

Reasoning: she has brisk, likely ongoing lower GI bleeding with recent hemodynamic instability. CT angiography rapidly localizes active bleeding (and can detect bleeding rates that are higher than the RBC scan), is noninvasive, and guides urgent catheter angiography/embolization if needed. Capsule endoscopy is for subacute/obscure small‑bowel bleeding after negative EGD/colonoscopy and is inappropriate in the setting of an acute, potentially brisk bleed because it is slow, not therapeutic, and may miss fast bleeding.

question: A 42-year-old female patient comes to the office with a 2-week history of intermittent, dull low back pain following a slip on a wet floor. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and her only medication is a multivitamin. Vital sign are within normal limits. On physical examination in the prone position, the following finding are noted: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Mild tenderness over the sacrotuberous ligament * Deep sacral sulcus on the right * Posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left * Lumbosacral junction that does not spring freely on compression * L5 flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. right sacral torsion on a right oblique axis B. left sacral torsion on a left oblique axis C. right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis D. right sacral rotation around a left oblique axis E. unilateral sacral flexion on the left F. left sacral rotation around a left oblique axis G. unilateral sacral extension on the right H. anterior sacral base dysfunction I. bilateral sacral flexion J. left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis
solution_text: left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis
default:
Backward sacral torsion — sacrum rotated right on a left oblique axis (R on L).  
Findings: deep right sacral sulcus, posterior/inferior left ILA, non‑springing sacrum and L5 nonneutral (F Rr Sr) are classic for an R on L backward torsion.
alternative: left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: left-on-right sacral torsion (sacral rotation to the left about a right oblique axis).

Reasoning: A deep right sacral sulcus with a posterior inferior lateral angle on the left is the classic palpatory pattern of an oblique-axis torsion. L5 is flexed, rotated right and sidebent right — L5 typically rotates opposite the sacrum in a torsion, so an L5 rotated right predicts sacral rotation to the left, consistent with an L-on-R torsion. Mild sacrotuberous tenderness and a non‑springing lumbosacral junction further support a sacral torsion.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: left unilateral sacral extension (left sacral base posterior).

Reasoning: A deep right sacral sulcus with a posterior–inferior left ILA and a positive sacral spring (L/S junction that does not spring anteriorly) indicate the left sacral base is held posterior (extension) with compensatory anterior motion on the right. In a true oblique-axis torsion the pattern of L5 and the spring test would differ (L5 typically rotates opposite the sacrum in a torsion); here L5 is flexed, rotated right, sidebent right and the spring test is restricted — findings that fit a left unilateral sacral extension rather than a left-on-left torsion.
raw_c:
Left-on-left (L on L) sacral torsion — a forward torsion with the sacrum rotated left about the left oblique axis.

Reasoning: the exam shows a deep right sacral sulcus with a posterior/inferior left ILA (classic opposite-sided sulcus/ILA pattern for an oblique-axis torsion about the left axis). L5 is flexed, rotated and sidebent right — in a forward sacral torsion L5 typically rotates opposite the sacrum, which fits an L on L torsion. The sacrotuberous tenderness and reduced lumbosacral spring further support a sacral torsion.
raw_d:
Conclusion: Left-on-right sacral torsion — left sacral rotation about a right oblique axis.

Reasoning: A deep sacral sulcus on the right with a posterior/inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left is the classic sulcus/ILA pattern for a left rotation about a right oblique axis. The L5 found flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right (F R R) is the expected lumbar coupling with a left-on-right sacral torsion, supporting that diagnosis.

question: A 68-year-old right-handed male is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset weakness. He woke up with clumsiness in his left hand, which quickly progressed to weakness on his left side, more pronounced in the arm than the leg. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, but he has not refilled his medication in a year. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Vital sign reveal a temperature of 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse of 98/min, respirations of 20/min, and blood pressure of 200/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows slurred speech, left-sided facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 strength in the left upper limb, and 4/5 strength in the left lower limb, with normal strength and sensation on the right side. MRI reveals a right-sided infarct in the paramedian pontine base. Which additional finding is most likely in this patient?
options: A. Ipsilateral tongue deviation B. Contralateral loss of proprioception C. Contralateral hemiparesis sparing the face D. Eye deviation to the left E. Vertical gaze palsy F. Ipsilateral facial weakness involving the forehead G. Eye deviation to the right H. Loss of pupillary light reflex on the right I. Bitemporal hemianopia J. Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing
default: Upper motor neuron signs on the left — increased tone and deep tendon reflexes with an upgoing plantar response (left Babinski).
raw_a:
Your answer is correct: conjugate deviation of the eyes to the left (away from the right pontine lesion). 

Reason: a right paramedian pontine base infarct often injures the right PPRF/abducens system → loss of gaze to the right (ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy), so the eyes rest deviated toward the intact side (left), accompanying the contralateral hemiparesis from corticospinal tract involvement.
raw_b:
Right-sided horizontal (conjugate) gaze palsy — inability to look to the right with either eye.

Reason: a paramedian pontine base infarct commonly involves the PPRF/abducens nucleus in the ipsilateral pons (causing an ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy) along with corticospinal/corticobulbar tract involvement (contralateral hemiparesis and lower-face weakness). The pupillary light reflex is mediated in the midbrain (III), so pupillary loss would not be expected from a pontine lesion.
raw_c:
A left-sided upper motor neuron pattern: increased tone and hyperreflexia with an upgoing plantar response (positive Babinski) on the left.

Reason: a right paramedian pontine base infarct damages descending corticospinal (and corticobulbar) fibers, producing contralateral (left) UMN signs such as weakness greater in the arm, hyperreflexia and an extensor plantar response.
raw_d:
You are correct — conjugate eye deviation to the left.

A right paramedian pontine base infarct likely injures the right PPRF/abducens complex (horizontal gaze center), causing loss of gaze to the right; the intact left gaze center drives the eyes to the left (deviation away from the lesion). Cortical frontal-eye-field lesions produce the opposite (eyes deviate toward the lesion).

question: A child is brought to the general practitioner with a three-day history of cough and runny nose. Yesterday, the child developed a fever but remains energetic, playful, and is eating well. The child attends daycare, and an older sibling recently had similar symptom. The child has no significant medical history, is up-to-date on vaccinations, and has no history of hospitalizations or surgeries. The child takes a vitamin D supplement and has no known allergies. On examination, the child appears well, is playing and engaging with the examiner. The child can hop on one foot but cannot stand on one foot for more than two seconds, throws a ball overhead, draws a person with 2-3 parts, sings, and can state their full name. Based on this information, which is the best conclusion?
options: A. The child should be able to write their full name at this stage B. This child is very likely to be 6 years old C. The child's fine motor skills suggest developmental delay D. The child's social development suggests autism spectrum disorder E. The child's gross motor skills are advanced for age F. The child's drawing abilities indicate above-average development G. This child is 3 years old H. The child's language skills are below age-appropriate levels I. It is expected for this child to able to  tell stories at his age J. This child very likely is not able to use scissors
solution_text: It is expected for this child to able to  tell stories at his age
default: This is most consistent with an uncomplicated viral upper respiratory infection in a well child who is developmentally normal for preschool age (about 3–4 years). The motor, language and drawing skills shown are appropriate overall, so reassure and provide symptomatic care; no urgent investigations or referral for developmental delay are indicated.
alternative: It is expected for this child to able to  tell stories at his age
raw_a:
Conclusion: This child is well-appearing with a likely viral URI and is developmentally appropriate for about 3–4 years — outpatient symptomatic care is appropriate; being able to tell stories is a somewhat more advanced (≈4-year) language skill and is not required if the child is nearer 3 years.

Reasoning: The child is playful, eating, vaccinated and has mild upper respiratory symptoms after daycare exposure, so no red flags for hospitalization. Motor and fine‑motor/language milestones (hops on one foot, stands on one foot only briefly, draws a 2–3 part person, throws overhead, sings, gives full name) fit the 3–4 year range and are within normal variation; therefore lack of clear story-telling alone is not concerning.
raw_b:
Conclusion: the child is about 4 years old.

Reasoning: hopping on one foot is a 4‑year gross motor milestone (standing on one foot for longer intervals comes a bit later), overhead ball throw and ability to sing/recite a name fit the 3–4 year range, and drawing a person with 2–3 parts and stating a full name are consistent with a preschooler around 4. Overall the profile fits a 4‑year‑old more closely than a 3‑year‑old.
raw_c:
The child is approximately 3 years old.

Reason: the combination of milestones—drawing a person with 2–3 parts, throwing a ball overhead, singing and stating their full name—classicy matches a 3-year-old. Balance (standing on one foot only ~2 seconds) and emerging hopping are also consistent with variation seen at age 3. Developmental milestones vary between children, so the overall profile best fits a 3‑year‑old.
raw_d:
Conclusion: The child’s developmental profile is most consistent with about a 4-year-old, and yes — being able to tell simple stories is expected at this age.

Reasoning: Hopping on one foot is typically a 4‑year gross motor milestone; being able to throw overhead, sing, and give a full name fit the 3–4 year range. Drawing a person with 2–3 parts is more typical of 3 years but falls within normal variation. Overall the skills indicate age‑appropriate development around 4 years, including story-telling.

question: A 16-year-old male with panhypopituitarism presents with progressive weight gain following surgical removal of a craniopharyngioma three years ago. Post-surgery, he developed panhypopituitarism and diabetes insipidus, requiring multiple hormone replacements including hydrocortisone (15 mg AM, 10 mg PM), growth hormone, levothyroxine, testosterone, and vasopressin. His weight, previously at the 50th percentile with BMI at the 80th percentile at the time of surgery, has increased to above the 99th percentile for both measurements. Current laboratory results show: | | Patient value | Reference range | | --- | --- | --- | | Insulin-like growth factor 1 (ng/mL) | 355 | 182–780 | | Free thyroxine (ng/dL) | 1.40 | 0.54–2.23 | | Testosterone, total (ng/dL) | 412 | 270–1070 | | Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL) | 0.02 | 0.5–4.0 | What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's obesity?
options: A. Leptin deficiency secondary to hypothalamic dysfunction B. Persistent diabetes insipidus causing compensatory hyperphagia C. Iatrogenic Cushing syndrome due to long-term glucocorticoid therapy D. Excessive testosterone replacement E. Hypothalamic injury F. Excess hydrocortisone replacement G. Secondary adrenal insufficiency due to improper hydrocortisone dosing H. Insufficient thyroid hormone replacement I. Growth hormone deficiency J. Pituitary dysfunction causing metabolic dysregulation
default: Most likely hypothalamic obesity from surgical damage to the hypothalamus (especially the ventromedial/arcuate satiety centers) after craniopharyngioma resection. His pituitary-hormone replacements are adequate by labs (normal free T4, IGF‑1 and testosterone), so the progressive, severe weight gain is best explained by hypothalamic injury causing hyperphagia, decreased energy expenditure and autonomic/metabolic dysregulation (leptin resistance, hyperinsulinemia).
raw_a:
Most likely cause: hypothalamic obesity from damage to the hypothalamic satiety/energy‑balance centers (post‑craniopharyngioma/surgical injury).

Reasoning: he has panhypopituitarism and DI after craniopharyngioma surgery — classic for hypothalamic injury. Thyroid, GH (IGF‑1), and testosterone are in replacement range, and the low TSH is expected with central hypothyroidism on levothyroxine, so under‑replacement of thyroid or sex steroids is unlikely. Although glucocorticoid timing/dose can worsen weight, his total hydrocortisone is within typical replacement range. The massive, progressive weight gain despite apparently adequate hormone replacement fits hypothalamic obesity (loss of satiety, hyperphagia, reduced energy expenditure and sympathetic tone), which is difficult to treat.
raw_b:
Most likely cause: iatrogenic glucocorticoid over‑replacement (Cushingoid obesity) from his hydrocortisone regimen—especially the substantial evening dose.

Reasoning in brief: IGF‑1, free T4 and testosterone are in acceptable ranges (so GH, thyroid and gonadal replacement appear adequate) and TSH is expectedly low with central replacement. His total hydrocortisone (25 mg/day) with a 10 mg evening dose is nonphysiologic and can produce weight gain/central obesity. Hypothalamic injury can also cause severe post‑craniopharyngioma obesity, but the medication pattern and adequacy of other hormone replacements make glucocorticoid over‑replacement the more likely driver here. Consider reducing/redistributing hydrocortisone to a more physiologic morning‑weighted schedule and checking a 24‑h urinary free cortisol or late‑night salivary cortisol to confirm overexposure.
raw_c:
Conclusion: Hypothalamic injury (post‑craniopharyngioma hypothalamic obesity).

Reasoning: He has classic features of hypothalamic damage after craniopharyngioma/surgery (panhypopituitarism, diabetes insipidus) and progressive, rapid weight gain to morbid obesity despite hormone replacement. Other causes are unlikely: thyroid and gonadal axes appear adequately replaced (FT4 and testosterone in acceptable ranges), IGF‑1 is normal on GH therapy, and steroid dosing is within typical replacement range. Hypothalamic/ventromedial nucleus injury causes hyperphagia, impaired satiety, leptin resistance and decreased energy expenditure, producing the severe, treatment‑resistant obesity seen here.
raw_d:
Most likely cause: hypothalamic injury causing hypothalamic obesity from the craniopharyngioma/surgery.

Reasoning: the dramatic, progressive weight gain after craniopharyngioma resection is classic for hypothalamic obesity (disordered satiety, hyperphagia, decreased energy expenditure, leptin/insulin dysregulation). His free T4 is in the normal range (and in central hypothyroidism you target free T4 rather than TSH), IGF‑1 and testosterone are acceptable — so inadequate thyroid (or gonadal/GH) replacement is unlikely to explain this degree of weight gain. Glucocorticoid overtreatment can contribute, but the clinical picture and history point to hypothalamic damage as the primary cause.

question: A 35-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. She underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy a week ago, during which she received a prophylactic dose of cefotetan. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any family history of genetic condition. On examination, her temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical finding include jaundice and splenomegaly. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL (previously 13.2 g/dL one week ago). Additional test reveal: Leukocyte count: 7,000/mm³ Platelet count: 300,000/mm³ Mean corpuscular volume: 90 µm³ Reticulocyte count: 9% Lactate dehydrogenase: 480 U/L (Normal: 140-280 U/L) Haptoglobin: 10 mg/dL (Normal: 41-165 mg/dL) Indirect bilirubin: 2.7 mg/dL D-dimer: <250 ng/mL (Normal: <250 ng/mL) A peripheral blood smear shows reticulocytosis and microspherocytes. Following appropriate initial management, which is the most suitable next diagnostic test?
options: A. Cold agglutinin titer B. Bone marrow biopsy C. Peripheral blood smear for Heinz bodies D. Hemoglobin electrophoresis E. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) enzyme assay F. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)-specific flow cytometry G. Indirect Coombs test H. Serum free hemoglobin level I. Direct Coombs test J. Osmotic fragility test
default: Direct antiglobulin (direct Coombs) test — to confirm immune (drug‑induced/warm) hemolytic anemia from cefotetan by detecting IgG and/or complement bound to the patient's RBCs.
raw_a:
The most appropriate next diagnostic test is a direct antiglobulin (direct Coombs) test.

Reason: The acute hemolysis with jaundice, splenomegaly, reticulocytosis, low haptoglobin, elevated LDH, and microspherocytes after recent cefotetan exposure is most consistent with immune-mediated (warm/drug-induced) hemolytic anemia. A direct Coombs test detects IgG and/or complement on RBCs and will confirm immune hemolysis; serum free hemoglobin is nonspecific and not the diagnostic test of choice.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Perform a direct antiglobulin (direct Coombs) test. 

Reasoning: The presentation is acute hemolysis after cefotetan exposure with jaundice, high reticulocytes/LDH, low haptoglobin, and microspherocytes—classic for drug‑induced immune hemolytic anemia. The direct antiglobulin test detects RBC‑bound IgG/complement and is the appropriate diagnostic next step to confirm immune‑mediated hemolysis (and to guide stopping the drug and further immune workup). Tests for G6PD deficiency or an indirect Coombs would be less informative in this clinical context.
raw_c:
Yes — the most appropriate next test is the direct antiglobulin (direct Coombs) test.

Reasoning: the acute drop in Hb after cefotetan, jaundice, splenomegaly, reticulocytosis, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin, indirect hyperbilirubinemia and microspherocytes point to immune-mediated (extravascular) hemolysis — classically drug‑induced or warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The direct Coombs detects IgG and/or complement bound to RBCs and will confirm the diagnosis (if positive, an eluate can identify the antibody).
raw_d:
Direct antiglobulin test (direct Coombs).

Reason: The presentation—acute hemolysis after cefotetan, jaundice, splenomegaly, microspherocytes and reticulocytosis—is most consistent with drug‑induced immune (Coombs‑positive) hemolysis, which is diagnosed with the direct antiglobulin test. Serum free hemoglobin assesses intravascular hemolysis but is not the next best diagnostic test here (and would not distinguish immune from nonimmune causes).

question: A 30-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with worsening upper abdominal pain over the past hour. She reports initial dull stomach pain approximately 6 hours ago that has progressed and localized to the upper abdomen. She experienced one episode of emesis en route to the hospital. Her medical and family histories are unremarkable. She is in a monogamous relationship with her husband. She denies tobacco or alcohol use. Her only medication are folic acid and prenatal vitamins. Her vital sign show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate of 100/min, and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness but is otherwise normal. Laboratory finding are as follows: | Hemoglobin | 13.1 g/dL | | --- | --- | | Leukocyte count | 17,000/mm3 | | Serum | | | Urea nitrogen | 20 mg/dL | | Creatinine | 0.8 mg/dL | | Alkaline phosphatase | 79 U/L | | Bilirubin | | | Total | 1 mg/dL | | Direct | 0.3 mg/dL | Urinalysis demonstrates mild pyuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Pancreatitis B. Ovarian torsion C. Acute cholecystitis D. Acute cholangitis E. Diverticulitis F. HELLP syndrome G. Appendicitis H. Hepatic abscess I. Pyelonephritis J. Gastritis
default:
Acute appendicitis (appendix displaced upward by the gravid uterus).  
Rationale: in late pregnancy the enlarging uterus shifts the appendix upward so classic periumbilical pain that migrates and localizes to the RUQ, with fever, leukocytosis and mild pyuria, is most consistent with appendicitis rather than gallbladder or hepatic disease.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: acute appendicitis (appendix displaced upward by the gravid uterus).

Reasoning: classic course of periumbilical dull pain that localized over hours, fever and leukocytosis fit appendicitis. In late pregnancy the enlarged uterus pushes the appendix upward so pain can present in the right upper quadrant. Mild pyuria is commonly seen with appendicitis from adjacent inflammation and can mimic a UTI. Findings argue against acute cholangitis (no jaundice, only minimally elevated bilirubin, normal alkaline phosphatase). Imaging (RUQ/transabdominal ultrasound or MRI if ultrasound nondiagnostic) and surgical consultation are indicated.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: acute appendicitis (appendix displaced upward by the gravid uterus).

Reasoning: the history of initial vague periumbilical/epigastric pain that localizes over hours, fever, leukocytosis and vomiting is classic for appendicitis; in late pregnancy the enlarging uterus pushes the appendix upward so the pain localizes to the RUQ. Normal bilirubin/LFTs argue against biliary obstruction/acute fatty liver or HELLP, and pyuria can be seen with appendiceal inflammation (or from contamination) so a mild UA finding does not exclude appendicitis.
raw_c:
Acute appendicitis.

Reasoning: She had initial vague periumbilical/stomach pain that migrated and localized (now RUQ), with fever, leukocytosis and vomiting—classic for appendicitis. In pregnancy the enlarged uterus displaces the appendix upward so pain/localization can be in the RUQ. Mild pyuria can occur with appendiceal inflammation (sterile pyuria) and normal bilirubin/LFTs make acute cholecystitis/hepatitis less likely. Next steps: RUQ-focused ultrasound and, if inconclusive, MRI (preferred in pregnancy) for confirmation.
raw_d:
Acute appendicitis.

Reasoning: In pregnancy the gravid uterus displaces the appendix upward so appendicitis classically presents with RUQ pain, fever, leukocytosis and vomiting—exactly this picture. Mild pyuria is common from periappendiceal irritation. Acute cholangitis is unlikely because the Charcot triad includes jaundice and cholestatic LFT abnormalities (elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase), which are absent here (total bilirubin ~1 mg/dL, ALP not markedly elevated).

question: A 20-year-old male presents to the clinic one day after sustaining an injury to his left ankle while playing soccer. He reports tripping over another player’s foot, rolling his ankle inward, hearing a ‘pop,’ and experiencing sharp pain immediately afterward. He was able to bear some weight on the foot shortly after the injury. Examination of the left lower extremity reveals that his foot prefers inversion, with noticeable laxity at the ankle joint. Although he can bear weight, he describes moderate pain. Which additional finding is most likely on physical examination?
options: A. Ecchymosis over medial aspect B. Proximal fibular head posterior C. Calcaneus deviated laterally D. Decreased range of plantar flexion E. Positive Thompson test F. Distal fibula posterior G. Talar tilt toward midline H. Medial malleolus tender to palpation I. Point tenderness over deltoid ligament J. Left foot in dorsiflexion
default: A positive anterior drawer test of the ankle (increased anterior translation of the talus relative to the tibia), consistent with injury to the anterior talofibular ligament from an inversion sprain.
raw_a: No — the most likely finding is a positive anterior drawer test of the ankle (increased anterior translation of the talus), reflecting an anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) tear from an inversion injury. The ATFL is the ligament most commonly injured with inversion/popping and produces ankle laxity; you may also see lateral malleolar tenderness and, if the calcaneofibular ligament is involved, an increased talar-tilt.
raw_b:
Most likely finding: a positive anterior drawer test of the ankle with tenderness over the anterior lateral malleolus (rupture/attenuation of the anterior talofibular ligament).

Reasoning: an inversion (often with plantarflexion) injury classically tears the ATFL — the most commonly injured ligament in lateral ankle sprains. Patients often hear a pop, have lateral-sided pain and laxity, and show increased anterior translation of the talus on the tibia (positive anterior drawer). Dorsiflexion would not be the expected primary exam finding.
raw_c:
No — the most likely finding is a positive anterior drawer test (increased anterior translation of the talus), indicating injury to the anterior talofibular ligament. 

Reasoning: An inversion ankle injury with a “pop,” laxity, and ability to partially bear weight is classic for a lateral ligament sprain; the ATFL is the most commonly injured ligament in inversion injuries and produces anterior ankle instability on the anterior drawer maneuver.
raw_d:
No — the most likely finding is a positive anterior drawer test (increased anterior translation of the talus) with tenderness over the anterior talofibular ligament.

Reason: an inversion injury classically tears the lateral ligament complex—most commonly the ATFL—producing lateral ankle laxity and a positive anterior drawer. Posterior displacement of the proximal fibular head is not a typical consequence of an ankle inversion sprain.

question: Three days after an open cholecystectomy, a 76-year-old man is evaluated for fever and confusion. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit one year ago and denies alcohol use. His prior medication included lisinopril, metformin, and ipratropium. On examination, he appears acutely ill and lethargic. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/84 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. A 10-cm subcostal incision is dry with mild erythema, and there is tenderness in the lower abdomen without guarding or rebound. Pulmonary examination reveals scattered expiratory wheezes but no crackles. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A urinary catheter is in place, and urine output is normal. Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
options: A. Blood culture B. Urine culture C. Lumbar puncture D. Serum procalcitonin E. Complete blood count with differential F. Chest x-ray G. Abdominal CT H. Sputum culture I. Abdominal ultrasound J. Wound culture
default: Urinalysis with urine culture from the indwelling catheter (showing pyuria/bacteriuria and a significant colony count consistent with a catheter‑associated UTI).
raw_a:
Conclusion: Obtain a urinalysis with urine culture (ideally a specimen from a newly placed catheter) to confirm catheter-associated urinary tract infection.

Reasoning: On post-op day 3 an indwelling urinary catheter plus fever, acute confusion (delirium), and suprapubic/lower abdominal tenderness strongly suggest a catheter-associated UTI causing sepsis. A CBC is nonspecific; definitive diagnosis requires urinalysis (pyuria, nitrites/leukocyte esterase) and urine culture to identify the pathogen and guide therapy. (Replace the catheter and culture a fresh specimen before starting antibiotics.)
raw_b:
Conclusion: Obtain a urinalysis with a urine culture from the indwelling catheter (catheter-specimen urine) — this is the test most likely to confirm a catheter-associated UTI causing his fever and acute delirium.

Reasoning: Fever on postop day 3 with an indwelling catheter and new confusion in an elderly patient is classic for a CAUTI (older adults often present with delirium rather than urinary symptoms). The suprapubic/lower‑abdominal tenderness supports bladder source; the incision looks benign and there are no clear pulmonary consolidation signs. Urinalysis (pyuria, leukocyte esterase/nitrite) plus urine culture will identify and confirm the urinary source. (Blood cultures are indicated if you suspect bacteremia/sepsis, but the diagnostic test to confirm the likely source is urine testing.)
raw_c:
Urine culture — with an initial urinalysis/dipstick as a screen. 

Reason: New fever and acute confusion in a postop patient with an indwelling catheter strongly suggests catheter-associated UTI; urinalysis (pyuria/nitrites) screens, but definitive diagnosis requires a urine culture.
raw_d:
Urine culture.  

This presentation—fever, new-onset confusion in an elderly postoperative patient with an indwelling urinary catheter—most strongly suggests a catheter-associated UTI; urine culture is required to confirm the diagnosis and identify the organism/antibiotic sensitivities. A CBC may show leukocytosis but is nonspecific and cannot confirm the source; urinalysis is a useful rapid screen, and blood cultures should be obtained if systemic infection/sepsis is suspected.

question: A 34-year-old female presents to the clinic with low back pain. She was recently seen in the emergency department after falling off a ladder at which time a full workup, including a CT spine series, was negative for acute injury. She states the worst of the pain is improved but she continues to have residual discomfort. She describes the pain as achy, and it worsens when she lies down. On osteopathic structural examination, there is a right posterior transverse process palpated at the level of the spinous process of T10, which becomes more pronounced when the spine is extended. The paraspinal musculature is hypertonic and tender from T9–T12. Which is the correct diagnosis?
options: A. T11 FRRSR B. T10 FRRSR C. T10 FRLSL D. T9 ERRSR E. T9 FRRSR F. T11 ERRSR G. T10 ERRSR H. T11 FRLSL I. T12 ERRSR J. T12 FRRSR
default:
Somatic dysfunction of T10 — extended and rotated to the right (T10 E Rr). 

Explanation: a posterior transverse process indicates an extension dysfunction, and a posterior right transverse process indicates right rotation. The finding becomes more pronounced with extension, consistent with an extended, right-rotated single-level (Type II) somatic dysfunction.
raw_a:
The correct diagnosis is T11 extended, rotated right and sidebent right (T11 E RrSr — a Type II extension somatic dysfunction).

Reason: a posterior transverse process palpated one level above the spinous indicates the transverse process of T11; a posterior prominence that becomes more pronounced with extension indicates an extension dysfunction; rotation and sidebending occur to the same side in Type II dysfunction, so the posterior right TP = rotated and sidebent right.
raw_b:
Correct diagnosis: T10 extended, rotated right, side‑bent right (T10 E R R S R).

Reasoning: a posteriorly prominent right transverse process indicates a right rotation of that vertebra; the prominence increasing with extension identifies an extended (not flexed) dysfunction. The finding is localized at the level of the T10 spinous, so the dysfunctional segment is T10 rather than T9.
raw_c:
No — the correct diagnosis is T9 extended, rotated right, sidebent right (T9 E Rr Sr).

Reason: A posterior transverse process indicates rotation toward that side; the asymmetry is accentuated with extension, so it is an extended (not flexed) dysfunction. Because the posterior right TP is felt at the level of the spinous of T10, the dysfunctional segment is the vertebra above (T9). In a non‑neutral single‑segment (Type II) dysfunction rotation and sidebending occur to the same side.
raw_d:
No — the correct diagnosis is T9 extended, rotated right, sidebent right (T9 ERRSR).

Reasoning: the transverse process you palpated at the level of the T10 spinous process corresponds to the T9 transverse process (thoracic spinous processes project inferiorly). A posterior transverse process indicates rotation toward that side (right). It becomes more pronounced with extension, indicating an extended (non‑neutral) dysfunction. In Type II (non‑neutral) lesions, rotation and sidebending are to the same side, so the lesion is T9 E R S R.

question: A 72-year-old male farmer presents with a neck mass. He has avoided medical care for over three decades. His history includes smoking two packs of cigarettes daily since age 14 and weekly consumption of a six-pack of beer. The physical exam reveals poor dental health, multiple actinic keratoses, bilateral expiratory wheezes at the lung bases, and a 2.5-cm fixed, indurated mass on the right side of his neck. No supraclavicular lymph nodes are detected. Flexible laryngoscopy shows no abnormalities. His chest X-ray appears normal. Neck CT imaging reveals a 3-cm necrotic lymph node and several smaller nodes on the right side, with no other significant finding. A cervical lymph node biopsy confirms poorly differentiated squamous-cell carcinoma. Which diagnostic procedures is essential for the workup?
options: A. MRI of the brain B. Fine needle aspiration of contralateral lymph nodes C. Endoscopic examination of the upper esophagus D. Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy E. CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis F. Direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia and concurrent tonsillectomy G. PET-CT scan of head and neck H. Contrast-enhanced CT of brain and orbits I. MRI of the nasopharynx and skull base J. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy of primary site
solution_text: Direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia and concurrent tonsillectomy
default: Panendoscopy (triple endoscopy) under general anesthesia — i.e., direct inspection with rigid endoscopy of the upper aerodigestive tract (direct laryngoscopy, esophagoscopy and bronchoscopy) with systematic directed biopsies (including bilateral tonsillectomy and base‑of‑tongue mucosal biopsies) to look for an occult primary.
alternative: Contrast-enhanced CT of brain and orbits
raw_a:
Conclusion: The essential next diagnostic procedure is panendoscopy (direct laryngoscopy ± bronchoscopy and esophagoscopy) under anesthesia with directed biopsies — including ipsilateral tonsillectomy and base‑of‑tongue biopsies — to search for an occult primary. 

Reasoning: This patient has squamous cell carcinoma in a cervical node with no obvious primary on office laryngoscopy/CT. The standard workup for carcinoma of unknown primary in the neck is panendoscopy with systematic biopsies (tonsillectomy/base‑of‑tongue mucosectomy) to locate the occult mucosal tumor. PET‑CT is also commonly used to localize occult primaries pre‑operatively and p16/HPV testing on the nodal specimen should be obtained, but contrast CT of the brain/orbits is not the essential next step.
raw_b:
Essential test: whole-body FDG-PET/CT (head and neck ± chest) before operative exploration.

Reasoning: in a cervical node metastasis with unknown primary, PET/CT is the recommended initial step because it frequently localizes occult primaries (tonsil, base of tongue, oropharynx, etc.) and guides targeted biopsies. Direct laryngoscopy/tonsillectomy (or panendoscopy with directed biopsies) is important too but is best performed after PET/CT to direct the operative sampling; doing blind operative removal without PET guidance is not the current standard.
raw_c:
Conclusion: Perform an examination under anesthesia with panendoscopy (direct laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy and esophagoscopy) and directed biopsies—including ipsilateral tonsillectomy and base-of-tongue biopsy (or mucosectomy); obtain PET‑CT for occult‑primary search/staging. 

Reasoning: He has a metastatic cervical node with squamous carcinoma and no visible primary on flexible laryngoscopy. EUA/panendoscopy with directed biopsies (tonsil and base‑of‑tongue) is the standard to locate an occult head‑and‑neck primary; PET‑CT is now routinely used to localize occult primaries and stage disease.
raw_d:
No — contrast-enhanced CT of the brain/orbits is not essential here. The next essential diagnostic step is panendoscopy (direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia) with thorough endoscopic inspection of the upper aerodigestive tract and directed biopsies, typically including ipsilateral tonsillectomy (or bilateral/tonsillar and base-of-tongue sampling) to look for an occult primary. 

Reasoning: a necrotic cervical node with squamous carcinoma in an older smoker most commonly reflects an occult mucosal primary in the oropharynx/tonsil/base of tongue that can be missed on awake flexible laryngoscopy or CT neck. Panendoscopy with biopsy (and nowadays adjunctive PET–CT to localize an occult primary) is the standard workup. Brain/orbit CT is only indicated if focal neurologic signs or suspicion of intracranial disease.

question: A clinical trial investigated the effectiveness of CPAP therapy in preventing cardiovascular events among patient aged 45-75 with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea and established cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease. The study followed 2,717 participants for an average of 3.7 years, comparing CPAP plus usual care versus usual care alone. Based on the study's inclusion criteria, which patient would be most appropriate to apply these research finding to?
options: A. A 56-year-old male with a history of moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea. B. A 60-year-old female with mild obstructive sleep apnea and no cardiovascular disease. C. A 55-year old male with NYHA class III heart failure with a LVEF of 32%. D. A 62-year-old male with severe obstructive sleep apnea and poorly controlled hypertension. E. A 53-year-old female with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea and no history of cardiovascular disease. F. An 82-year-old female with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea. G. A 70-year-old male with severe obstructive sleep apnea and a history of myocardial infarction. H. A 67-year-old female with coronary artery disease and untreated mild sleep apnea. I. A 49-year-old male with severe obstructive sleep apnea but no history of cardiovascular disease. J. A 58-year-old male with moderate obstructive sleep apnea and stable angina.
solution_text: A 56-year-old male with a history of moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea.
default: A 60‑year‑old patient with prior myocardial infarction (established cardiovascular disease), newly diagnosed moderate obstructive sleep apnea (AHI ≈20–30 events/hour), aged between 45–75, and without marked daytime sleepiness — i.e., a patient matching the SAVE trial enrollment criteria.
alternative: A 56-year-old male with a history of moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea.
raw_a: No — include cardiovascular disease. The trial enrolled patients aged 45–75 with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea AND established cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease. So the most appropriate patient would be, for example, a 56-year-old man with moderate-to-severe OSA who also has a prior myocardial infarction (or known coronary artery disease or prior stroke).
raw_b:
Conclusion: A patient aged 45–75 who has moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea and established cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease — for example, a 62-year-old with moderate OSA and a prior myocardial infarction (or prior ischemic stroke).

Reasoning: The trial enrolled patients 45–75 years old with moderate-to-severe OSA and known cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease. A 49-year-old with severe OSA but no history of CVD would not meet the key “established cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease” inclusion criterion, so the trial results don’t directly apply to them.
raw_c:
A 62-year-old man with newly diagnosed severe obstructive sleep apnea and a prior myocardial infarction (stable coronary artery disease).

Reasoning: The trial enrolled patients aged 45–75 with moderate-to-severe OSA and established cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease, so a patient who meets all three criteria is the appropriate match.
raw_d: No — the correct application is to a patient aged 45–75 who has moderate-to-severe OSA and established cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease. For example: a 56-year-old man with moderate-to-severe OSA and a prior myocardial infarction. Reason: the trial enrolled adults 45–75 with moderate-to-severe OSA plus existing cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease.

question: A 33-year-old male presents to the office with a chief complaint of chronic lower back pain. The patient does not remember injuring his back but he states he does a lot of heavy lifting at his job. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication have only minimally alleviated his pain. On exam, there is tenderness over the lumbosacral region with a reduced lordotic curve. Seated and standing flexion test reveal no abnormalities. The sacral base is posterior bilaterally. There is movement restriction at the lumbosacral junction with anterior force. The flexion and extension of the sacrum during cranial rhythmic impulse are unremarkable. The straight leg test is negative and the rest of the examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Bilateral sacral torsion along the middle transverse axis B. Unilateral sacral flexion along the middle transverse axis C. Bilateral sacral flexion along the middle transverse axis D. Bilateral sacral extension along the superior transverse axis E. Bilateral sacral rotation along the middle transverse axis F. Bilateral sacral extension along the middle transverse axis G. Sacral base anterior with restriction along the superior transverse axis H. Bilateral sacral extension along the inferior transverse axis I. Bilateral sacral flexion along the superior transverse axis J. Bilateral sacral flexion along the inferior transverse axis
solution_text: Bilateral sacral extension along the middle transverse axis
default: Bilateral sacral extension dysfunction (bilateral posterior sacral bases). Findings: sacral bases posterior bilaterally, reduced lumbar lordosis, and a positive spring (restricted with anterior pressure) with normal seated/standing flexion tests.
