She describes the pain as "stabbing" and notes that it radiates to her flank. The symptom began during a high-intensity interval training class. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any regular medication. She is sexually active with a single partner and has a regular menstrual cycle, with her last period occurring one week ago. Vital sign include a temperature of 99.0°F, blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, pulse of 100/min, and respiratory rate of 15/min. Abdominal examination reveals a scaphoid, non-distended abdomen with tenderness in the right lower quadrant but no rebound or guarding. A serum pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography shows a round hyperechoic structure with hypoechoic stripes arranged concentrically. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
options: A. Ruptured ovarian cyst B. Hemorrhagic corpus luteum C. Appendiceal fecalith D. Adnexal torsion with ischemia E. Pelvic inflammatory disease F. Ovarian torsion G. Physiologic ovarian cyst H. Tubo-ovarian abscess I. Endometriotic cyst rupture J. Ectopic pregnancy
default: Ovarian torsion secondary to an ovarian mass — most likely a mature cystic teratoma (dermoid) whose echogenic, laminated contents produce the concentric/“whirlpool” ultrasound appearance, with twisting of the ovarian vascular pedicle causing acute ischemic pain.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Ovarian torsion secondary to a functional ovarian cyst (most likely a corpus luteum cyst) causing twisting of the adnexal vascular pedicle.

Reasoning: Young woman with sudden severe unilateral pelvic pain and nausea after exertion fits torsion. The US description of a round echogenic structure with concentric hypoechoic/hyperechoic stripes is the “whirlpool” sign of a twisted vascular pedicle. Functional cysts (eg, corpus luteum about 1 week after menses) commonly enlarge the ovary and precipitate torsion.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: ovarian torsion — twisting of the ovarian (adnexal) vascular pedicle.

Reasoning: acute, unilateral severe pelvic pain with nausea/vomiting precipitated by exertion is classic for torsion. The described ultrasound appearance (round mass with concentric hyperechoic/hypoechoic stripes) corresponds to the “whirlpool/target” sign of a twisted vascular pedicle/adnexa. Doppler flow can be preserved early, so lack of absent flow does not exclude torsion; this is a surgical emergency.
raw_c:
Yes — this is most consistent with ovarian torsion from twisting of the ovarian vascular pedicle.

Reasoning: the clinical picture (sudden severe unilateral pelvic pain with nausea/vomiting, onset with exertion) is classic for torsion. The described ultrasound appearance — a round echogenic structure with concentric hypoechoic stripes — is the “whirlpool” (target) sign created by the twisted ovarian pedicle/vascular cords. This produces venous/lymphatic congestion and ischemic pain and requires urgent surgical detorsion to try to preserve ovarian function.
raw_d:
Ovarian torsion — twisting of the ovarian vascular pedicle causing ischemia.

Reasoning: The presentation (sudden, severe unilateral pelvic pain with nausea/vomiting, precipitated by exertion) is classic for torsion. The sonographic description of concentric hyperechoic and hypoechoic bands is the “whirlpool/target” sign of a twisted pedicle. A simple physiologic ovarian cyst would usually appear as a thin‑walled, anechoic structure and is less likely to produce abrupt, severe pain.

question: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with an unintentional weight loss of 4.5 kg over the past two months. He reports generalized bone pain, abdominal discomfort, and malaise but denies symptom such as dyspnea, urinary issues (dysuria, hesitancy, urgency, or hematuria), constipation, or blood in his stools. He has a 2-pack-year smoking history but quit 30 years ago. Vital sign are within normal limits, and physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results reveal a hemoglobin level of 11.7 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5), a calcium level of 10.2 mg/dL (9.0–10.5), and an alkaline phosphatase level of 503 U/L (30–120). A complete metabolic profile and urinalysis are unremarkable. Imaging finding include: - Chest radiograph: Sclerotic bony lesions - Abdominal CT scan: Bulky para-aortic lymphadenopathy, widespread blastic bone metastases, no liver or lung masses, and a normal-appearing prostate CT-guided biopsy of the para-aortic lymphadenopathy shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Which is the most appropriate next diagnostic test for this patient?
options: A. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation B. CT-guided biopsy of a bone lesion C. Digital rectal examination and prostate-specific antigen test D. Thyroid ultrasound with fine-needle aspiration E. Carcinoembryonic antigen test followed by colonoscopy F. Chromogranin A and 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA levels G. Molecular tumor profiling of the sampled lymph node using gene expression analysis H. Upper endoscopy with biopsy I. Serum alpha-fetoprotein and beta-HCG levels J. Positron emission tomography with18 F-fluorodeoxyglucose
solution_text: Digital rectal examination and prostate-specific antigen test
default: Order a serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level (and if needed, perform PSA/PSAP or NKX3.1 immunohistochemical staining on the biopsy) — metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma is the most likely diagnosis given sclerotic bone mets in an older man.
alternative: Digital rectal examination and prostate-specific antigen test
raw_a:
Obtain a serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level and perform a digital rectal exam (and request PSA/PSAP immunohistochemical staining of the lymph‑node biopsy to confirm prostatic origin).

Reason: A 65-year-old man with sclerotic (blastic) bone metastases, bulky para‑aortic nodes and a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is most consistent with metastatic prostate cancer even if the prostate appears normal on CT. PSA/DRE are the appropriate next diagnostic tests; IHC for PSA/PSAP on the biopsy can definitively establish prostatic origin.
raw_b:
Most appropriate next test: immunohistochemical staining of the lymph‑node biopsy for prostate markers (eg, PSA, PSAP, NKX3.1).

Reasoning: In an older man with sclerotic/blastic bone metastases and poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in a para‑aortic node, prostate cancer is the leading diagnosis. Tissue IHC for prostate‑specific markers is the quickest, most specific way to establish prostatic origin (and is preferred before proceeding to broad molecular tumor‑of‑origin profiling, which is used when IHC is non‑diagnostic).
raw_c:
Obtain a serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level.

Reason: In an older man with sclerotic (osteoblastic) bone metastases, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in nodal biopsy, prostate cancer is the most likely primary—even with a normal-appearing prostate on CT and no urinary symptoms. PSA is the appropriate, noninvasive first diagnostic test; if PSA is elevated or ambiguous, confirm origin with prostate-directed evaluation and/or immunohistochemical staining (PSA/PSAP) on the biopsy.
raw_d:
Obtain a digital rectal exam (DRE) and serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA).

Reason: His age, diffuse sclerotic (blastic) bone metastases, high alkaline phosphatase and bulky para‑aortic nodal adenocarcinoma strongly suggest metastatic prostate cancer; the prostate can appear normal on CT. DRE and PSA are the appropriate, noninvasive initial tests and will guide further workup (and you can confirm origin by IHC for PSA/PSAP or NKX3.1 on the biopsy if needed).

question: A 35-year-old right-hand-dominant woman presents with a recurring painful bump on the dorsal aspect of her right wrist that has occurred three times over the past year. She denies any history of trauma to the wrist or hand. The bump has been increasing in size, is tender, and is interfering with her work as a transcriptionist. She has no numbness, tingling, recent illness, fever, or chills. On examination, a 2-cm mobile, rubbery, and tender mass is palpable over the radial carpal joint. There is no erythema or soft-tissue swelling. The mass limits the active range of motion in extension and radial flexion. Sensation is intact over the hand, capillary refill is 2+, and grip strength is 4/5 on the right compared to 5/5 on the left. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s condition?
options: A. Prescribe antibiotics to treat a possible underlying infection B. Perform aspiration of the mass with a needle C. Inject a glucocorticoid solution into the mass D. Order a biopsy of the mass to rule out malignancy E. Perform a nerve conduction study to assess for nerve involvement F. Obtain an MRI of the wrist to evaluate the mass further G. Recommend physical therapy to improve wrist strength H. Refer for surgical excision I. Reassure the patient, and observe the mass J. Prescribe NSAIDs and advise activity modification
default: This presentation is most consistent with a dorsal wrist ganglion that is recurrent, painful, and functionally limiting. The most appropriate next step is surgical excision (open removal including the ganglion stalk and adjacent capsular tissue) because aspiration has a high recurrence rate and observation is unlikely to relieve her symptoms.
alternative: Prescribe NSAIDs and advise activity modification
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: surgical excision of the dorsal wrist ganglion (open ganglionectomy with removal of the stalk).

Reasoning: The presentation is classic for a dorsal scapholunate ganglion. Because it has recurred multiple times over a year, is painful and functionally limiting her work, definitive surgical removal is indicated. Conservative measures (NSAIDs, splinting, aspiration) are reasonable for a first, minimally symptomatic lesion but have higher recurrence rates and are less appropriate for recurrent, symptomatic disease.
raw_b:
Refer her for surgical excision by a hand surgeon.

This is most consistent with a dorsal wrist (ganglion) cyst that has recurred multiple times and is painful and function-limiting. Aspiration +/- steroid has a high recurrence rate and is reasonable only if the patient wants a less invasive trial; however, for recurrent, symptomatic lesions that interfere with work, definitive excision (with repair of the stalk/joint capsule) is the preferred management. Obtain ultrasound (or radiographs/MRI) only if there is diagnostic uncertainty or concern for other pathology prior to surgery.
raw_c: Recommend surgical excision (referral to a hand surgeon) — this is a recurrent, painful dorsal wrist ganglion that has failed conservative/less definitive measures and is functionally limiting. Aspiration has a high recurrence rate and is less effective after multiple recurrences; definitive open (or arthroscopic) excision including the ganglion stalk reduces recurrence and restores function. Imaging is not required before referral unless findings are atypical.
raw_d:
Surgical excision (referral to hand surgeon) is the most appropriate next step.

This presentation is a classic dorsal wrist ganglion that is recurrent (three episodes), increasing in size, painful, and limiting function. Conservative measures (NSAIDs, activity modification) are reasonable for small, first-time or minimally symptomatic cysts, but recurrence and functional impairment make definitive treatment preferable. Aspiration has a high recurrence rate; excision of the cyst and its stalk offers the best chance of symptomatic relief and lower recurrence.

question: A 22-year-old female patient seeks medical attention due to progressive weight gain and hair loss over a two-year period. Her menstrual history includes menarche at age 12 with irregular cycles until complete cessation one year ago. Her physical measurements show a height of 165 cm, weight of 82 kg, and BMI of 30 kg/m2. Clinical examination reveals male-pattern hair loss, including a receding hairline and vertex baldness. Laboratory finding are as follows: | Test | Result | | --- | --- | | Thyroid-stimulating hormone | 2 μU/mL | | Luteinizing hormone | 32 mIU/mL | | Prolactin | 11 ng/mL | A pregnancy test is negative, and the patient demonstrates withdrawal bleeding following a progestin challenge. Which hormonal increase is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's amenorrhea?
options: A. Follicle-stimulating hormone in the pituitary gland B. Progesterone in corpus luteum C. Estrogen in adipose tissue D. Prolactin in the pituitary gland E. Insulin in pancreatic beta cells F. Cortisol in the adrenal cortex G. Androgens in the adrenal gland H. Progesterone in the corpus luteum I. Testosterone in peripheral tissues J. Growth hormone in the anterior pituitary
default: Increased ovarian androgen production—primarily testosterone (and androstenedione) from theca cells driven by an elevated LH (typical of PCOS). The high LH with normal prolactin/TSH and progestin-induced withdrawal bleeding (estrogen present) points to LH‑driven hyperandrogenism causing anovulation/amenorrhea.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Increased ovarian androgen (testosterone) production — i.e., hyperandrogenism from PCOS (LH-driven theca-cell testosterone) — is the most likely cause.

Reasoning: Obesity, male-pattern hair loss, long-standing oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea, markedly elevated LH with normal TSH and prolactin, and a positive progestin challenge (estrogen present but no ovulation) fit PCOS, where increased LH stimulates theca cells to make excess androgens (some of which are aromatized peripherally), causing anovulation and amenorrhea.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Increased ovarian androgen production (eg, testosterone/androstenedione) driven by elevated LH (as in PCOS) is the most likely cause.

Reasoning: The picture (obesity, male-pattern hair loss, long-standing oligomenorrhea → amenorrhea, very high LH with normal TSH/prolactin, positive progestin withdrawal) is classic for PCOS. In PCOS an ↑LH/FSH ratio stimulates theca cells to overproduce androgens (testosterone/androstenedione), causing hirsutism and anovulation (no corpus luteum → low progesterone). The positive withdrawal bleed shows adequate estrogen and an intact outflow tract, so the problem is androgen-driven anovulation, not excess corpus luteal progesterone.
raw_c:
No — the most likely cause is increased ovarian androgen production (elevated testosterone/androstenedione) driven by an increased LH:FSH ratio (PCOS).

Reasoning: the patient has obesity, hirsutism/male-pattern hair loss and long-standing menstrual irregularity with high LH. A positive progestin challenge shows adequate estrogen and an intact outflow tract, so amenorrhea is from chronic anovulation due to hyperandrogenism (excess ovarian testosterone/androstenedione), not lack of progesterone.
raw_d:
No — the most likely cause is increased ovarian androgen production (elevated testosterone) driven by LH (PCOS).

Reasoning: The combination of obesity, male-pattern hair loss, an elevated LH, chronic anovulation with withdrawal bleeding after progestin, and amenorrhea fits polycystic ovary syndrome. In PCOS increased LH → increased theca cell androgen (testosterone) production, causing hyperandrogenic features and anovulation. Peripheral estrone from adipose may be present but is not the primary cause.

question: A 78-year-old female smoker presents to urgent care after a syncopal episode. Her grandson reports finding her conscious on the living room floor after hearing a thud. The patient recalls feeling lightheaded upon standing to use the bathroom, followed by a sudden loss of consciousness. She reports similar previous episodes without falls or fainting. There was no witnessed seizure activity, urinary, or bowel incontinence. Her medical condition include osteoporosis treated with alendronate and rheumatoid arthritis managed with low-dose methotrexate. Vital sign show temperature 97°F (36.1°C), blood pressure 105/62 mmHg, pulse 68/min, respirations 13/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a tender 3-cm ecchymosis on the right upper extremity. While awaiting laboratory results, radiography of the right upper extremity, and head CT, which finding is most likely to be revealed during further evaluation?
options: A. Elevated serum creatinine kinase B. Orthostatic hypotension C. New ST-elevation on electrocardiogram D. Abnormal carotid doppler findings E. Decreased serum calcium F. Decreased hemoglobin G. Prolonged QT interval on electrocardiogram H. Elevated troponin levels I. Carotid sinus hypersensitivity J. Decreased fractional excretion of sodium
default: An x-ray of the right upper extremity is most likely to show an osteoporotic proximal humerus (humeral neck) fracture from the fall.
raw_a:
Conclusion: You would most likely find orthostatic hypotension — a drop in systolic BP ≥20 mm Hg (or diastolic ≥10 mm Hg) on standing.

Reasoning: The syncopal episode occurred immediately on standing with preceding lightheadedness, no seizure features, and normal pulse — classic for orthostatic (postural) syncope in an elderly patient. Fractional excretion of sodium is unrelated to this presentation (it's used to evaluate causes of acute kidney injury).
raw_b:
Conclusion: Orthostatic hypotension — a drop in systolic BP of ≥20 mmHg (often with little compensatory tachycardia) on standing.

Reasoning: The event began with lightheadedness on standing and she has prior similar presyncopal episodes, classic for orthostatic syncope in an older adult. There is no chest pain or ischemic prodrome to suggest acute STEMI (so new ST elevations on ECG are unlikely), and head CT/X‑ray are more likely to be negative or show only minor trauma from the fall. Measuring orthostatic vitals is the next most likely diagnostic finding.
raw_c:
Most likely finding: a postural drop in blood pressure consistent with orthostatic hypotension (≥20 mm Hg fall in systolic BP on standing, often with minimal compensatory tachycardia).

Reasoning: she had lightheadedness on standing followed immediately by syncope, recurrent presyncopal episodes, no seizure features, and stable pulse/oxygenation — classic for orthostatic syncope. The bruise is from the fall; the CT/x-ray are to exclude trauma.
raw_d:
Your answer is more likely correct — a decreased fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) is the most likely finding.

Reasoning: her syncope began with lightheadedness on standing, consistent with orthostatic (volume‑depletion) syncope in an elderly patient. That would produce prerenal azotemia (elevated BUN:Cr) and a low FeNa (<1%). New ST‑elevation is unlikely given the absence of chest pain, ischemic symptoms, or hemodynamic instability.

question: A 6-month-old female infant is evaluated for progressive eye crossing, particularly noticeable before bedtime. The child was delivered by C-section at 37 weeks, has achieved age-appropriate developmental milestones, and is current with vaccinations. She plots at the 50th percentile for both length and weight. Vital sign show: temperature 36.7°C (98°F), pulse 130/min, respirations 40/min, and blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg. Examination reveals 20/20 vision in both eyes with asymmetric corneal light reflection. A cover test of the left eye results in lateral movement of the right eye. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Application of cyclopentolate drops to the left eye B. Immediate ophthalmology consultation C. Patching of the right eye D. Surgical correction of strabismus E. Application of atropine drops to both eyes F. Vision therapy exercises G. Reassurance and follow-up H. Bilateral eye patching I. Prescription of corrective lenses J. MRI of the brain and orbits
solution_text: Application of cyclopentolate drops to the left eye
default: This presentation is consistent with pathologic strabismus (esotropia) in an infant. The most appropriate next step is urgent referral to a pediatric ophthalmologist for full evaluation (including cycloplegic refraction) and prompt management (eg, corrective lenses and/or patching or surgical correction) to prevent amblyopia.
alternative: Application of cyclopentolate drops to the left eye
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: perform cycloplegic refraction (cyclopentolate drops to both eyes) to assess for hyperopic accommodative esotropia.

Reason: asymmetric corneal light reflex and cover test findings indicate an esotropia in an infant — accommodative (hyperopic) esotropia is common and treatable with corrective lenses. Cycloplegic refraction (using cyclopentolate) is required before considering patching or surgery and to prevent amblyopia; refer to pediatric ophthalmology if abnormal.
raw_b:
Most appropriate next step: urgent referral to a pediatric ophthalmologist for a full eye exam with cycloplegic refraction (not immediate patching).

Reasoning: A new, progressive esotropia at 6 months warrants prompt specialist evaluation to rule out underlying ocular disease, measure refractive error (to detect an accommodative component), and determine definitive therapy (eyeglasses, early surgical alignment, or occlusion if amblyopia develops). Patching is a treatment for established amblyopia or as an adjunct after specialist-directed management, not the first step in an infant with newly detected strabismus.
raw_c:
Refer urgently to a pediatric ophthalmologist for complete evaluation including cycloplegic refraction (do not immediately start patching).

Reason: the cover test shows a true tropia (the right eye moves laterally when the left is covered → right esotropia). Strabismus persisting at 6 months requires prompt specialist assessment to determine cause (refractive/accommodative vs. infantile strabismus or structural lesion) and to institute appropriate therapy (glasses for accommodative esotropia, patching only if amblyopia is present, and/or surgical alignment).
raw_d:
Not exactly — the best next step is to obtain a cycloplegic refraction (apply cyclopentolate to both eyes) and arrange prompt pediatric ophthalmology evaluation.

Reason: the asymmetric corneal light reflex and cover test show a manifest esotropia. Before instituting patching for amblyopia you must check for refractive (accommodative) esotropia and correct any hyperopia with spectacles; cycloplegic refraction (cyclopentolate) is the appropriate next diagnostic/therapeutic step. Patching is reserved later if amblyopia persists after refractive correction.

question: A 50-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, portal hypertension, esophageal varices, and hepatic encephalopathy is brought in with new-onset confusion. Her husband, though unfamiliar with her chronic condition, confirms she regularly takes spironolactone, labetalol, lactulose, and furosemide. Her vital sign show: - Temperature: 38.3°C (100.9°F) - Heart rate: 110/min - Respiratory rate: 16/min - Blood pressure: 98/60 mm Hg - Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air Clinical examination reveals disorientation, lethargy, poor command response, and mild asterixis. Her abdomen is distended, tense, and mildly tender. Cardiac exam is unremarkable and lungs are clear. Stool is guaiac negative. Laboratory finding include: | Basic metabolic panel | Unremarkable | | --- | --- | | Platelet count | 95,500/µL | | Leukocyte count | 14,790/µL | | Hematocrit | 33% (baseline is 30%) | | Hemoglobin | 13.0 g/dL | Which diagnostic test would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
options: A. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) B. Serum ammonia level C. Measurement of lactate levels D. Blood cultures E. Stool culture F. Abdominal ultrasound with Doppler G. Diagnostic abdominal paracentesis H. Liver biopsy I. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis J. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy
default: Diagnostic paracentesis with ascitic fluid analysis (cell count with neutrophil/PML count, Gram stain and culture). SBP is diagnosed if ascitic fluid PMNs ≥250 cells/mm3 (and/or positive culture).
raw_a:
Most helpful test: diagnostic paracentesis with ascitic fluid analysis (cell count with differential and culture).

Reasoning: This patient with cirrhosis and tense ascites plus fever, abdominal tenderness, leukocytosis and new/worsening encephalopathy is highly suspicious for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The definitive diagnosis is an ascitic fluid PMN count >250 cells/mm3 and/or positive culture. Liver biopsy is unnecessary and risky in cirrhosis (coagulopathy/thrombocytopenia).
raw_b:
Conclusion: Diagnostic abdominal paracentesis (ascitic fluid analysis with cell count/PMN, Gram stain and culture) is the single most useful test to establish the diagnosis — specifically to detect spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

Reasoning: A cirrhotic patient with tense ascites, fever, new encephalopathy, hypotension and leukocytosis has a high pretest probability of SBP. The diagnostic criterion is ascitic neutrophils (PMNs) ≥250 cells/mm3; cultures/Gram stain confirm the organism. Guidelines recommend urgent paracentesis in any cirrhotic patient with ascites who has fever, abdominal pain/tenderness, encephalopathy, hypotension or leukocytosis. Blood cultures are useful adjuncts but do not replace ascitic fluid analysis. Coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia (platelets ≈95K) is not a contraindication to bedside paracentesis.
raw_c:
Yes — perform an urgent diagnostic abdominal paracentesis with ascitic fluid cell count (PMNs) and culture.

Reasoning: A cirrhotic patient with ascites who develops fever, leukocytosis and new encephalopathy is highly suspicious for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The diagnostic criterion is ascitic fluid neutrophils >250 cells/mm3 (and culture/cell count confirms organism). Peritoneal signs may be absent in SBP, and thrombocytopenia/coagulopathy are not absolute contraindications to paracentesis. Obtain fluid for cell count, Gram stain and culture (and total protein/albumin) before antibiotics if possible.
raw_d:
No — the best test is diagnostic abdominal paracentesis.

Reason: In a cirrhotic patient with tense ascites, fever, abdominal tenderness, leukocytosis and new/worse encephalopathy the leading concern is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). SBP is diagnosed by paracentesis with ascitic fluid PMN count >250 cells/mm3 and cultures. Liver biopsy is invasive, unnecessary for this acute presentation, and carries increased risk in cirrhosis/ascites (coagulopathy, bleeding) and would not establish SBP. Obtain ascitic fluid (ideally before antibiotics) and send for cell count, differential and culture.

question: A 20-year-old male college student arrives at the emergency department with several days of back pain and fatigue. He recently returned from a study abroad trip to Morocco, where he participated in activities such as swimming at the beach, eating local foods like couscous and bean salad, and riding a camel in the desert. His vital sign include a temperature of 99°F (37°C), blood pressure of 121/79 mmHg, pulse of 70/min, and respirations of 11/min. He reports otherwise good health but notes episodes of dark urine. On physical examination, his skin appears more yellow than usual, particularly under his eyelids. Which finding is most likely in this patient?
options: A. Absent urine bilirubin B. Positive Coombs test C. Increased direct bilirubin in serum D. Decreased urine urobilinogen E. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia F. Increased serum haptoglobin levels G. Hemoglobinuria H. Dark stools due to excess stercobilin I. Elevated urine bilirubin J. Increased indirect bilirubin in serum
default: Acute hepatitis A infection. You would most likely find a positive anti‑HAV IgM (acute HAV) with markedly elevated ALT/AST and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with bilirubinuria (positive urine bilirubin).
raw_a:
Conclusion: Urine bilirubin would be present (positive urine bilirubin/conjugated bilirubin in urine).

Reasoning: His history of eating local food in Morocco, prodrome of fatigue, dark urine and scleral jaundice is most consistent with acute viral hepatitis (eg, hepatitis A). In hepatocellular/posthepatic jaundice the bilirubin is conjugated (water‑soluble) and is excreted in urine, so urine bilirubin is positive (whereas in hemolytic jaundice unconjugated bilirubin is absent from urine).
raw_b:
Most likely finding: bilirubinuria from conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (eg, elevated serum direct bilirubin with positive urine bilirubin and markedly elevated ALT), consistent with acute hepatitis A (anti-HAV IgM positive).

Reasoning: travel and ingestion of local food → acute viral hepatitis; jaundice and dark urine are from water‑soluble conjugated bilirubin excreted in urine (not hemoglobinuria from hemolysis).
raw_c: Heinz bodies (denatured/precipitated hemoglobin) on the peripheral blood smear — consistent with G6PD deficiency causing acute hemolysis after ingestion of fava beans (bean salad), producing back pain, dark urine, jaundice, ↑ indirect bilirubin, ↓ haptoglobin and hemoglobinuria.
raw_d:
Correct — Absent urine bilirubin. 

This picture (back pain, dark urine, scleral icterus after eating bean salad) fits acute intravascular hemolysis (eg, G6PD “favism”); hemolysis raises unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin, which is albumin‑bound and not water‑soluble, so urine bilirubin is negative even though urine may be dark from hemoglobinuria and increased urine urobilinogen.

question: A 46-year-old male presents with a 4-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and decreased appetite. He underwent a kidney transplant from a living relative five years ago and is currently on sirolimus and mycophenolate therapy. His blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. Laboratory finding reveal normocytic, normochromic anemia and a serum creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL, whereas his vital sign and lab results were normal six months ago. What is the most likely mechanism responsible for the increase in this patient’s creatinine concentration?
options: A. CD8+ T cell-mediated parenchymal cell damage B. Drug-induced tubular vacuolization C. CD4+ T cell-mediated intimal smooth muscle proliferation D. Mycophenolate-associated bone marrow suppression leading to renal hypoperfusion E. Fibrosis secondary to recurrent glomerulonephritis F. Chronic ischemic injury due to donor-specific antibodies G. Calcineurin inhibitor-induced vasoconstriction H. Antibody-mediated endothelial cell injury I. Sirolimus-induced tubular epithelial cell apoptosis J. Tubulointerstitial inflammation from viral reactivation
solution_text: CD4+ T cell-mediated intimal smooth muscle proliferation
default: Chronic (late) allograft rejection — a host immune response (cellular and humoral) against donor antigens causing progressive intimal thickening of graft vessels and interstitial fibrosis/tubular atrophy. This vascular narrowing and scarring reduce renal perfusion and GFR, raising serum creatinine (and causing ↓EPO → normocytic anemia).
alternative: CD4+ T cell-mediated intimal smooth muscle proliferation
raw_a:
Conclusion: Correct — chronic (host) immune) rejection with CD4+ T cell–mediated intimal smooth muscle proliferation (chronic graft vasculopathy) is the most likely mechanism.

Reasoning: The progressive rise in creatinine 5 years after transplant, new hypertension and gradual decline over months is classic for chronic allograft rejection rather than acute rejection or drug nephrotoxicity. Chronic rejection is driven by recipient T cells (and chronic humoral responses) causing fibrointimal thickening of graft vessels, ischemia, interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy → progressive loss of graft function. The patient’s immunosuppressive regimen (sirolimus + mycophenolate, not calcineurin inhibitors) also makes chronic immune-mediated injury more likely than calcineurin-induced arteriolar hyalinosis.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Chronic (immune‑mediated) allograft rejection — progressive transplant vasculopathy with intimal thickening causing ischemia, tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis — is the most likely mechanism.

Reasoning: The problem developed years after transplant with a gradual rise in creatinine, new hypertension and normocytic anemia, which fit chronic allograft nephropathy (chronic rejection) rather than acute drug toxicity. Drug‑induced tubular vacuolization is classically seen with calcineurin inhibitors (cyclosporine/tacrolimus) producing acute hemodynamic injury; this patient is on sirolimus and mycophenolate, which are not typical causes of that pattern.
raw_c:
Conclusion: Chronic allograft rejection (chronic transplant nephropathy) — immune‑mediated vascular and interstitial injury (intimal thickening, interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy) causing progressive loss of GFR and rise in creatinine.

Reasoning: The time course (months–years post‑transplant), progressive creatinine rise with new hypertension and anemia is classic for chronic rejection. Mechanistically it’s host immune injury (cellular and humoral) producing vascular intimal hyperplasia/obliteration and chronic ischemic fibrosis of the graft, reducing effective filtration.
raw_d:
You are correct. The most likely mechanism is chronic (host) immune–mediated rejection — CD4+ T cell–driven intimal smooth muscle proliferation leading to vascular narrowing and progressive allograft ischemia.

Reasoning: graft dysfunction developing months–years after transplant with gradual creatinine rise, new hypertension and anemia is classic for chronic rejection (chronic allograft vasculopathy). Pathology shows intimal thickening from cytokine-driven smooth muscle proliferation (and often concurrent chronic antibody‑mediated injury), whereas drug tubular vacuolization is seen with calcineurin inhibitors and/or causes different, often more acute, patterns of injury.

question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to a 4-hour history of hand pain. His mother reports that the pain has only slightly improved with ibuprofen. He has no prior history of similar episodes. The child was born at term and has otherwise been healthy. His family moved to the United States from Equatorial Guinea 2 years ago. On examination, he appears to be in acute distress. His temperature is 38.2ºC (100.8ºF), pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 28/min. The fingers of both hands are tender, warm, erythematous, and edematous. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
options: A. Peripheral blood smear B. Blood culture C. X-ray of the hands D. Joint aspiration and culture E. Nailfold capillary microscopy F. Serum ferritin levels G. Complete blood count with differential H. Serum uric acid level I. Hemoglobin electrophoresis J. C-reactive protein measurement
default: Hemoglobin electrophoresis to confirm sickle cell disease (suspected dactylitis from vaso‑occlusive infarction in a young child of African origin).
raw_a:
Hemoglobin electrophoresis.

Reason: The presentation (fever and painful, swollen erythematous fingers = dactylitis) in a toddler from Equatorial Guinea is classic for vaso‑occlusive sickle cell disease. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the definitive diagnostic test to detect HbS and confirm sickle cell disease; a peripheral smear may show sickled cells but is not diagnostic.
raw_b:
Most appropriate initial diagnostic test: peripheral blood smear (with CBC and reticulocyte count).

Reasoning: This presentation—acute, bilateral painful, swollen fingers in a toddler from sub‑Saharan Africa—is classic for vaso‑occlusive dactylitis from sickle cell disease. A peripheral smear/CBC is rapid and will show sickled red cells, anemia, and reticulocytosis; hemoglobin electrophoresis can be done afterward to confirm the diagnosis. Hand X‑rays are not the initial test for suspected dactylitis.
raw_c:
Hemoglobin electrophoresis.

Reason: The bilateral painful, warm, swollen fingers in a 3-year-old from Equatorial Guinea are most consistent with dactylitis from vaso-occlusive sickle cell disease; electrophoresis (or hemoglobin testing) is the appropriate test to confirm sickle cell (HbS).
raw_d:
Peripheral blood smear.

This presentation is classic dactylitis (hand swelling/pain) from vaso-occlusive infarction in young children with sickle cell disease; a peripheral smear (with CBC/retic count) can quickly show sickled cells and other hemolytic changes. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used afterward for definitive diagnosis; plain radiographs are not diagnostic acutely and are reserved if concern for fracture/osteomyelitis.

question: A 31-year-old female North African immigrant seeks emergency care for hematemesis occurring over the past three days. Her examination reveals: - Tachycardia with normal blood pressure - Tender hepatomegaly - No sign of chronic liver disease or ascites - Melena on rectal examination Laboratory finding show: - Hematocrit: 25.0% (reference: 36.0–46.0%) - Mean corpuscular volume: 70 μm3 (reference: 80–100) - Normal international normalized ratio, liver function, and total bilirubin After receiving two units of packed red blood cells, upper endoscopy reveals large esophageal varices and old blood in the stomach, without active bleeding. Which diagnostic test would most likely identify the underlying etiology of her condition?
options: A. Hepatitis B surface antigen test B. Doppler ultrasonography of the liver C. Liver biopsy D. Upper gastrointestinal series with barium swallow E. Abdominal CT scan F. Serum ferritin and transferrin saturation levels G. Echinococcal antigen test H. Schistosoma serology test I. Serum alpha-fetoprotein level J. Stool ova and parasites test
default: Stool ova-and-parasite examination (eg, Kato–Katz) to detect Schistosoma mansoni eggs — schistosomal periportal fibrosis (presinusoidal portal hypertension) fits her varices with preserved liver function and North African origin.
raw_a:
Answer: Serologic testing for Schistosoma mansoni (or stool ova examination for S. mansoni eggs).

Reason: The presentation (esophageal variceal bleeding with hepatomegaly but preserved synthetic liver function and no stigmata of cirrhosis) in a North African immigrant is classic for chronic schistosomal periportal fibrosis causing presinusoidal portal hypertension. Serology or stool O&P for S. mansoni would identify the cause. Echinococcal antigen testing is incorrect — hydatid disease causes hepatic cysts, not the noncirrhotic portal hypertension/varices seen here.
raw_b:
Order schistosomal serology (eg, serum anti‑Schistosoma antibodies — ELISA); this will most likely identify schistosomal portal fibrosis as the cause.

Reasoning: a young North African with hepatomegaly, large esophageal varices but preserved liver synthetic function points to presinusoidal portal hypertension from Schistosoma (S. mansoni) periportal fibrosis. Stool O&P is often negative in chronic infection, so serology (and supportive abdominal ultrasound showing periportal fibrosis) is more sensitive.
raw_c:
Serologic testing for Schistosoma (eg, anti–Schistosoma mansoni antibodies).

Reasoning: Large esophageal varices with preserved liver function and tender hepatomegaly in a North African immigrant is most consistent with hepatosplenic schistosomiasis (presinusoidal portal hypertension from periportal fibrosis). Stool ova can be negative in chronic infection, so serology (and ultrasound showing periportal “pipe‑stem” fibrosis) is the most sensitive test to identify schistosomal etiology.
raw_d:
No — the most likely test is serologic testing for Schistosoma (eg, schistosomal antibody), not echinococcal antigen.

Reasoning: A young North African immigrant with massive esophageal varices, hepatomegaly, melena and preserved liver synthetic function points to presinusoidal portal hypertension from hepatosplenic schistosomiasis (periportal fibrosis). Serology (or stool/urine ova detection) for Schistosoma species is the appropriate diagnostic test; echinococcal antigen detects hydatid cyst disease, which typically presents with hepatic cysts rather than this clinical syndrome.

question: A 30-year-old primigravida at 40 weeks gestation presents in active labor with regular contractions. Her pregnancy is significant for a 48-pound weight gain. She reports no fluid leakage, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Her previous delivery was vaginal at 37 weeks. She takes only prenatal vitamins. Vital sign show temperature 36.9°C, pulse 88/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 116/74 mmHg. The patient is admitted after pelvic examination, receives an epidural, and shows Category I fetal heart tracings. A repeat cervical exam several hours later shows no change from the initial assessment. Labor arrest is diagnosed and cesarean delivery is recommended. Which sets of finding would justify this diagnosis and management decision? | | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | A | 5 cm / 50% / -1 cm | 6 hours | Ruptured | 240 | | B | 10 cm /100%/ +3 cm | 2 hours | Ruptured | 200 | | C | 6 cm / 60% / 0 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 180 | | D | 7 cm / 70% / +1 cm | 4 hours | Intact | 250 | | E | 8 cm / 80% / +1 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 220 |?
options:
A. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 8 cm / 85% / +1 cm | 2 hours | Ruptured | 240 | B. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 8 cm / 80% / +1 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 220 | C. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 6 cm / 60% / 0 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 180 | D. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 9 cm / 90% / +2 cm | 5 hours | Intact | 200 | E. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 6 cm / 65% / -1 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 280 | F. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 7 cm / 70% / +1 cm | 4 hours | Intact | 250 | G. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 10 cm /100%/ +3 cm | 2 hours | Ruptured | 200 | H. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |

| 5 cm / 50% / -1 cm | 6 hours | Ruptured | 240 | I. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 7 cm / 75% / 0 cm | 3 hours | Ruptured | 260 | J. | Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 7 cm / 70% / 0 cm | 6 hours | Intact | 230 |
solution_text:
| Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 8 cm / 80% / +1 cm | 4 hours | Ruptured | 220 |
default:
E

Rationale: ACOG criteria for arrest of active-phase dilation (≥6 cm) require no cervical change for ≥4 hours with adequate contractions (≥200 MVU). Option E meets all: 8 cm unchanged for 4 hours, ruptured membranes, and MVU 220 (adequate).
alternative:
| Exam results (dilation / effacement / station) | Time between initial and repeat exams | Membrane status | Montevideo units (MVU) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 7 cm / 70% / 0 cm | 6 hours | Intact | 230 |
raw_a:
Answer: E.

Reason: Active-phase arrest is diagnosed when there is no cervical change for ≥4 hours with adequate uterine activity (≥200 Montevideo units) once dilation is ≥6 cm. Option E (8 cm, no change for 4 hours, membranes ruptured, MVU 220) meets these criteria and justifies cesarean delivery.
raw_b:
Answer: E.

Reasoning: Current criteria define the active phase as ≥6 cm. Active‑phase arrest is no cervical change for ≥4 hours with adequate uterine activity (≥200 Montevideo units). Option E shows 8 cm with no change for 4 hours and MVU 220 (adequate) with ruptured membranes, which meets the indication for cesarean. Other choices fail: A is <6 cm (still early labor under modern definitions), C has inadequate MVU (180), D has intact membranes (you would perform amniotomy/augmentation before deeming arrest), and B is already second stage with only 2 hours elapsed (does not meet second‑stage arrest criteria).
raw_c:
E.

Reason: She has no cervical change for 4 hours with ruptured membranes and adequate uterine activity (MVU 220 ≥200). An absence of dilation in the active phase for ≥4 hours with adequate contractions justifies diagnosing active‑phase arrest and proceeding to cesarean.
raw_d:
No — the best answer is E (8 cm / 80% / +1, 4 hours, ruptured, MVU 220).

Reasoning: Active-phase arrest in a nulliparous patient is lack of cervical change for ≥4 hours with adequate contractions (≥200 MVU) once in active labor (≥6 cm). Option E meets all criteria (active phase, adequate MVUs, 4 hours no change, membranes already ruptured). In contrast, your suggested scenario (7 cm, 6 hours, intact, MVU 230) has intact membranes — amniotomy (and augmentation if needed) should be attempted before declaring arrest and proceeding to cesarean.

question: An 18-year-old female presents to the emergency department with right lower abdominal pain that began 6 hours ago, rating it as 8/10. She experienced a similar episode the previous month. Her family history includes a brother with perforated appendicitis and a mother with diverticulitis. Her menstrual history reveals menarche at age 14 with regular 28-day cycles, with her last period occurring 2 weeks ago. She reports being sexually active with multiple partners and inconsistent condom use. Vital sign show: Temperature 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure 110/74 mmHg, pulse 89/min, respirations 14/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals moderate distress with lower abdominal tenderness and guarding. Pelvic examination shows clear mucous in the vaginal introitus, a mobile uterus, and right adnexal tenderness. Laboratory results: - Leukocyte count: 10,000/mm^3 with normal differential - Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL - Platelet count: 200,000/mm^3 - Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin: Pending Pelvic ultrasound reveals a small fluid collection in the cul-de-sac posterior to the uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Functional ovarian cyst B. Endometriosis C. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy D. Ovarian cyst rupture E. Acute appendicitis F. Tubo-ovarian abscess G. Acute salpingitis H. Midcycle pain I. Mesenteric adenitis J. Pelvic inflammatory disease
default:
Most likely diagnosis: Mittelschmerz (ovulatory pain from rupture of the ovarian follicle).

Reason: pain began midcycle (2 weeks after menses), prior similar monthly episode, localized adnexal tenderness with small posterior cul‑de‑sac fluid on ultrasound (consistent with follicular rupture), normal WBC and stable vitals arguing against acute infection or torsion/rupture with hemorrhage.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Pelvic inflammatory disease (acute salpingitis).

Reasoning: Sexually active with multiple partners and inconsistent condom use, acute lower abdominal pain with right adnexal tenderness, and pelvic ultrasound showing cul‑de‑sac fluid fit the CDC criteria for presumptive PID. Normal WBC/low-grade temp do not exclude PID. Ectopic pregnancy and appendicitis are considerations (check beta‑hCG, urine pregnancy, and evaluate appendix on exam/imaging), but the sexual risk factors and adnexal findings make PID most likely.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Mittelschmerz (ovulatory pain from follicular rupture).

Reasoning: Pain began ~14 days after the last period in a woman with regular 28‑day cycles (timing consistent with ovulation), she has had a similar monthly episode before, vitals and WBC are normal, pelvic exam lacks purulent discharge or marked cervical motion tenderness, and transvaginal ultrasound shows a small posterior cul‑de‑sac fluid collection consistent with physiologic fluid after follicular rupture. Important: obtain the beta‑hCG to exclude pregnancy/ectopic and re-evaluate urgently if pain worsens, fever develops, hemodynamic instability, or signs of adnexal mass/torsion.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: Mittelschmerz — ovulation pain from follicular rupture (or small corpus luteum hemorrhage).

Reasoning: The pain began ~2 weeks after her last period and she had a similar monthly episode previously, consistent with midcycle timing. Exam shows focal right adnexal tenderness, vitals and WBC are not suggestive of infection, and pelvic US shows a small posterior cul-de-sac fluid collection consistent with recent follicular rupture. Ectopic pregnancy should be excluded with the pending β-hCG, and ovarian torsion is less likely given absence of an enlarged ovary, severe systemic signs, or Doppler flow abnormalities. Monitor and reassess if pain worsens or β-hCG is positive.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: Mittelschmerz (mid‑cycle ovulatory pain).

Reasoning: The pain began abruptly midcycle (LMP 2 weeks ago) and recurred monthly, is unilateral with only right adnexal tenderness, minimal systemic signs (low‑grade temperature, normal WBC), clear mucous, and a small cul‑de‑sac fluid consistent with follicular rupture/ovulatory fluid. PID would more likely cause bilateral adnexal/cervical motion tenderness, purulent discharge, fever and leukocytosis. Continue pregnancy test and STI testing to exclude ectopic pregnancy and confirm/rule out PID as needed.

question: A 27-year-old woman reports experiencing vulvar pain, itching, dysuria, and urethral discharge for the past three days. Her symptom are accompanied by fever, malaise, myalgias, and headaches. She describes severe pain during urination, leading her to avoid using the toilet. She recently returned from a tropical vacation, during which she engaged in multiple unprotected sexual encounters with both men and women. Her vital sign include a temperature of 38.7°C (101.6°F), heart rate of 90/min, and respiratory rate of 16/min. On pelvic examination, there are vulvar ulcers and excoriations without vesicles, as well as erythema and edema of the vaginal mucosa, but no purulent discharge. Which test or characteristic is most effective in identifying the subtype of the causative organism?
options: A. Tzanck smear B. Culture in Thayer-Martin agar C. Serology D. Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) E. Dark-field microscopy F. PCR amplification of viral DNA G. Direct fluorescence antigen (DFA) H. Viral culture with typing I. Western blot analysis J. Gram stain of urethral discharge
default: Nucleic acid amplification (PCR) of a lesion swab using type-specific primers (or type-specific serology for glycoprotein G) — PCR is the most sensitive and specific way to distinguish HSV‑1 from HSV‑2.
raw_a:
No — the best test is nucleic acid amplification with genotyping (eg, PCR of the ompA gene with sequencing or LGV-specific PCR), not DFA.

Reason: the clinical picture fits lymphogranuloma venereum from Chlamydia trachomatis L1–L3. DFA can detect Chlamydia antigen but cannot reliably distinguish serovars; molecular NAATs with targeted genotyping (or serovar‑specific monoclonal antibody/sequence analysis) are required to identify the subtype.
raw_b:
Conclusion: This is most consistent with chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi), and nucleic acid amplification testing (PCR/genotyping) is the most effective method for identifying and subtyping the organism.  

Reasoning: The presentation—painful ragged vulvar ulcers (no vesicles), severe dysuria, recent tropical travel and multiple partners—fits chancroid rather than syphilis (painless chancre) or HSV (vesicular lesions). Dark-field microscopy is used for Treponema pallidum (syphilis) and is therefore incorrect here. H. ducreyi can be suggested by a characteristic “school‑of‑fish” appearance on Gram stain and grown on special media, but PCR/NAAT is the most sensitive and specific method for definitive identification and subtyping.
raw_c:
No — this is most consistent with genital herpes. The best test to identify the subtype (HSV‑1 vs HSV‑2) is a type‑specific serologic assay that detects antibodies to glycoprotein G (gG).  

Reason: the presentation fits primary genital herpes (vesicles often rupture into ulcers and cause severe dysuria and systemic symptoms). Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells but cannot type the virus; culture or NAAT/PCR can detect virus from lesions (and PCR with type‑specific probes also types), but gG‑based serology is the classic, widely used method to distinguish HSV‑1 from HSV‑2.
raw_d: You’re right — direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing of lesion scrapings is an appropriate rapid method to identify the HSV subtype. DFA uses type‑specific antibodies to distinguish HSV‑1 from HSV‑2; a Tzanck smear only shows multinucleated giant cells (no typing), and dark‑field microscopy is for Treponema pallidum. PCR is an alternative with even higher sensitivity and can also be type‑specific.

question: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a three-month history of peripheral neuropathy, skin changes, and unintentional weight loss of 7.5 kg. He reports progressive tingling, numbness, and weakness in both upper and lower extremities, which now interfere with routine tasks, such as gripping objects or standing from a chair. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no daily medication. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmented and hypertrichotic skin areas, along with red-purple lesions on the torso and proximal extremities. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted on abdominal examination. Neurologic evaluation shows symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy in all extremities. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin of 19 g/dL, platelet count of 600,000/µL, and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone. Serum protein electrophoresis demonstrates a monoclonal M-protein spike. Radiographs show osteosclerotic bone lesions in the proximal extremities. Electromyography (EMG) reveals low motor amplitudes and delayed nerve conduction. Which finding is most likely present in this patient?
options: A. Elevated serum vascular endothelial growth factor B. Anti-MAG antibodies C. Elevated serum POEMS antibodies D. Anti-contactin-1 antibodies E. Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of the bone marrow F. Elevated TNF-alpha levels G. Autoantibodies to neurofascin H. Anti-ganglioside antibodies I. Elevated serum cryoglobulin J. Increased IL-6 levels
default: This presentation is classic for POEMS syndrome (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal protein, skin changes). The most likely additional finding is markedly elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) levels.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Markedly elevated serum vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) — consistent with POEMS syndrome (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, M‑protein, skin changes).

Reasoning: The combination of symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy, hepatosplenomegaly, endocrinopathy (↑TSH), hyperpigmentation/hypertrichosis, red‑purple skin lesions, thrombocytosis/erythrocytosis, monoclonal M‑protein with osteosclerotic lesions is classic for POEMS (usually λ‑restricted plasma cell disorder). POEMS is characterized by markedly increased VEGF, which explains the vascular/skin findings and many systemic features. Autoantibodies to neurofascin are not characteristic of this syndrome.
raw_b:
Elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) levels.

Reason: This clinical picture is classic for POEMS syndrome (Polyneuropathy, Organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal protein, Skin changes) which is characteristically associated with markedly increased VEGF (not primarily IL‑6). VEGF elevation explains the edema, skin/vascular changes, and many systemic features; the monoclonal protein is usually a lambda-restricted plasma cell clone.
raw_c:
No — the most likely finding is markedly elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) levels.

Reasoning: This presentation fits POEMS syndrome (Polyneuropathy, Organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal plasma cell disorder, Skin changes) with osteosclerotic lesions, thrombocytosis/polycythemia, hypothyroidism, and a monoclonal M-protein. VEGF is characteristically elevated in POEMS and drives many of the vascular/skin and neuropathic manifestations.
raw_d:
No — the most likely finding is markedly elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

Reasoning: His constellation of symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy (↑TSH), skin changes, monoclonal M‑protein and osteosclerotic lesions fits POEMS syndrome; VEGF is the characteristic and pathogenic lab abnormality in POEMS (often correlates with disease activity). Autoantibodies to neurofascin are associated with certain CIDP/paranodal neuropathies, not with POEMS.

question: A 7-year-old male with severe persistent asthma presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress lasting 3 days. His history includes recent hiking in Colorado with acetazolamide use for altitude sickness (discontinued 7 days ago), followed by a 4-day episode of vomiting and diarrhea that resolved 2 days prior. Current symptom include coughing, wheezing, and dyspnea. Covid-19 vaccination is current and SARS-CoV-2 testing is negative. Physical examination reveals an uncomfortable-appearing patient with heart rate 148/min, respiratory rate 44/min, and oxygen saturation 91% on room air. Chest examination shows diffuse bilateral wheezing. After treatment with multiple albuterol nebulizers, IV methylprednisolone, and magnesium, he is placed on continuous albuterol and transferred to intensive care. The next morning, wheezing has resolved but significant tachypnea persists. Laboratory results at 24 hours show: | | Patient value | Reference range | | --- | --- | --- | | Sodium (mEq/liter) | 138 | 135–147 | | Potassium (mEq/liter) | 3.2 | 3.4–4.7 | | Chloride (mEq/liter) | 104 | 97–107 | | Bicarbonate (mEq/liter) | 15 | 22–26 | | Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL) | 16 | 5–18 | | Creatinine (mg/dL) | 0.7 | 0.3–0.7 | | Glucose (mg/dL) | 121 | 60–100 | | Venous pH | 7.25 | 7.31–7.41 | What is the most likely cause of this patient's metabolic derangement?
options: A. Primary respiratory alkalosis B. Renal tubular acidosis C. Diarrhea D. Dehydration-induced metabolic acidosis E. Lactic acidosis F. Ingestion of acetazolamide G. Metabolic compensation for respiratory alkalosis H. Magnesium-induced metabolic acidosis I. Steroid-induced metabolic acidosis J. Beta-agonist induced ketoacidosis
default: Most likely: lactic (high‑anion‑gap) metabolic acidosis from prolonged high‑dose beta‑2 agonist (continuous albuterol) therapy. Beta‑2 stimulation increases glycolysis/lactate production and shifts K+ intracellularly (explaining the hypokalemia). Acetazolamide or recent diarrhea would cause a non‑gap (hyperchloremic) acidosis and are less consistent with the findings.
raw_a:
Most likely cause: lactic acidosis from high‑dose β2‑agonist therapy (continuous albuterol) / ongoing metabolic demand from severe asthma.

Reasoning: labs show a high‑anion‑gap metabolic acidosis (AG = 138 − [104+15] = 19) with low HCO3 and low pH. Prolonged/severe asthma and continuous high‑dose β2‑agonists commonly produce lactic acidosis. Acetazolamide would produce a non‑AG (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis and was stopped 7 days ago, and the prior diarrheal bicarbonate loss would also cause a non‑AG acidosis and had resolved—so those are less likely.
raw_b:
Conclusion: This is most likely lactic (high‑anion‑gap) metabolic acidosis from intensive beta‑2 agonist therapy (continuous albuterol), not from acetazolamide or diarrheal bicarbonate loss.

Reasoning: labs show an elevated anion gap (138 − [104+15] = 19) with low HCO3 and acidemia, persistent tachypnea despite resolved wheeze and adequate oxygenation argues for metabolic (not primary respiratory) acidosis driving hyperventilation. The child has hypokalemia, tachycardia and mild hyperglycemia—findings typical of large doses/continuous beta‑2 agonist exposure. Beta‑2 stimulation increases glycolysis and lactate production (type B lactic acidosis). Acetazolamide causes a non‑anion‑gap (renal bicarbonate wasting) acidosis and was stopped a week ago, and diarrheal acidosis is usually non‑AG; renal failure and DKA are not supported.
raw_c:
Conclusion: High‑anion‑gap metabolic acidosis from lactic acidosis due to heavy β2‑agonist exposure and increased work of breathing.

Reasoning: Anion gap = 138 − (104 + 15) = 19 (elevated), so this is an AG metabolic acidosis. Diarrhea or prior acetazolamide would produce a non‑AG (hyperchloremic) acidosis and acetazolamide was stopped 7 days ago. The patient received prolonged/continuous albuterol and still has marked tachypnea; β2‑agonists and respiratory muscle overwork both increase lactate production. The concomitant hypokalemia also fits β2‑agonist effect.
raw_d:
Most likely cause: lactic (high–anion gap) metabolic acidosis from heavy beta‑2 agonist use/ongoing tissue hypoxia (albuterol‑associated lactic acidosis and/or lactate from respiratory muscle work).

Reasoning: anion gap = 138 − (104 + 15) = 19 (elevated), consistent with high‑AG metabolic acidosis (not the normal‑AG hyperchloremic acidosis seen with acetazolamide). The patient received repeated/continuous albuterol and remained tachypneic and relatively hypoxic — both promote lactate generation and beta‑agonists directly increase lactate and cause K+ shifting (explains hypokalemia). Acetazolamide causes a non‑AG (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis and was stopped 7 days ago, so it is unlikely here.

question: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to a well-child visit with concerns about persistent rightward head turning. His mother reports attempting to correct this by repositioning his head during sleep, without success. She is uncertain about the onset timing. The infant experienced a fall from bed the previous day but was easily consoled. He is meeting developmental milestones, including solid food introduction, babbling, and sitting with support. Birth history includes cesarean delivery at 37 weeks for breech presentation. Vital sign show: temperature 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure 87/53 mmHg, pulse 112/min, and respirations 29/min. Physical examination reveals right head turn with left head tilt, minor bruising on the posterior head and sternocleidomastoid muscle. Vision appears normal with appropriate focusing ability. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Reassurance and follow-up in one month B. Cranial ultrasound C. Observation and reassessment in two weeks D. CT scan of the head E. MRI of the cervical spine F. Trial of neck stretching exercises G. Neck radiograph H. Ophthalmology referral I. Referral to physical therapy J. Referral to a pediatric neurologist
default: This presentation is most consistent with congenital muscular torticollis. With a normal neurologic and ocular exam and age 6 months, the next step is conservative management: initiate pediatric physical therapy with caregiver-directed passive stretching of the affected SCM, positioning strategies (increased tummy time, encouraging head turning toward the non‑preferred side), and close follow‑up. Reserve imaging, botulinum injection, or surgical release only if therapy fails or if neurologic/ocular abnormalities or red flags develop.
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: begin conservative management — initiate neck-stretching exercises and refer for pediatric physical therapy (tummy time and repositioning strategies).

Reasoning: This presentation (head tilt to the left with chin rotated to the right, history of breech delivery, palpable SCM bruising) is classic congenital muscular torticollis from SCM tightness. In the absence of neurologic deficits, ocular abnormality, fever, worsening symptoms, or concerning acute trauma, imaging (neck radiograph) is not indicated initially. Early PT and home stretching have high success; reserve imaging/surgical referral only if no improvement after appropriate conservative treatment or if red flags develop.
raw_b:
Most appropriate next step: Begin conservative management for congenital muscular torticollis — start home stretching/positioning and refer to pediatric physical therapy.

Reasoning: The exam (rightward face rotation with left head tilt, tender/bruised left SCM, history of breech delivery) is classic for a left-sided congenital muscular torticollis (SCM shortening), not primary neurologic or ocular disease. Vision is intact and developmental milestones are appropriate. Management is gentle passive stretching of the affected SCM (tilt the infant’s head away from the affected side and rotate toward it to lengthen the muscle), increased tummy time and repositioning, and PT referral. Obtain hip screening (risk of developmental dysplasia of the hip) and consider ultrasound of the SCM only if a discrete mass or atypical features are present. If no improvement after several months of therapy or if progressive/atypical signs develop, escalate (imaging, ortho/pediatric surgery).
raw_c:
Begin conservative treatment for congenital muscular torticollis: start targeted passive stretching/positioning and refer to pediatric physical therapy.

Reasoning: The head turn to the right with left head tilt, SCM bruising/history of breech delivery, and normal vision/neurologic exam point to congenital muscular torticollis rather than ocular or neurologic causes. First-line management in infants is therapist-guided stretching and repositioning; imaging or specialist referral/surgery is only needed if there’s no improvement with therapy.
raw_d:
No — do not obtain a neck radiograph. The most appropriate next step is conservative management: start daily passive stretching/positioning and refer to pediatric physical therapy for congenital muscular torticollis.

Reasoning: The pattern (head tilt toward one side with rotation to the opposite side), history of breech delivery/C‑section, and palpable SCM findings are classic for congenital muscular torticollis. Vision is normal and the minor fall was trivial, so there is no red flag for cervical spine injury that would warrant radiographs. Ultrasound of the SCM can be obtained only if the diagnosis is uncertain or to evaluate a palpable mass.

question: A 9-year-old boy presents with a one-day history of red-colored urine, nonspecific abdominal pain, and discomfort during urination. He denies having fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. Vital sign are normal. On examination, he appears visibly uncomfortable and exhibits diffuse abdominal tenderness, which is more pronounced on the left side. Urinalysis demonstrates 3+ blood, 2+ protein, a specific gravity of 1.015 (reference range, 1.001–1.035), and a pH of 7.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0). There are no white cells, nitrites, ketones, or glucose detected. Urine microscopy reveals >100 red blood cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2). Additional laboratory results are as follows: | | Patient value | Reference range | | --- | --- | --- | | Sodium (mEq/L) | 139 | 135–147 | | Potassium (mEq/L) | 3.7 | 3.4–4.7 | | Chloride (mEq/L) | 108 | 97–107 | | Bicarbonate (mEq/L) | 22 | 22–26 | | Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL) | 16 | 5–18 | | Creatinine (mg/dL) | 0.6 | 0.3–0.7 | | Glucose (mg/dL) | 98 | 60–100 | What is the most appropriate next step to evaluate this patient?
options: A. 24-hour urine collection B. Complete blood count C. Measurement of complement levels D. Urine culture E. Renal ultrasound F. Voiding cystourethrogram G. Renal biopsy H. Antistreptolysin O titer I. CT scan of abdomen and pelvis J. Urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio
default:
Obtain a renal/bladder ultrasound to evaluate for nephrolithiasis/hydronephrosis. 

Rationale: gross hematuria with flank/left abdominal pain and dysuria in a child is most consistent with a urinary stone; ultrasound is the preferred first-line imaging in children to detect stones and hydronephrosis while avoiding ionizing radiation (noncontrast CT reserved if ultrasound is nondiagnostic but suspicion remains high).
raw_a:
Most appropriate next step: Renal/ureteral ultrasound.

Reasoning: Gross hematuria with severe microscopic hematuria (>100 RBC/hpf) and unilateral abdominal/flank pain suggests nephrolithiasis or a structural/obstructive process rather than UTI (there is no pyuria or nitrites). In children, ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging to look for stones or hydronephrosis and avoids ionizing radiation. A urine culture is not indicated first-line here because findings do not support infection.
raw_b: Renal (kidney/bladder) ultrasound — because this presentation (acute unilateral abdominal/flank pain with gross hematuria, >100 RBC/HPF, no pyuria or nitrites) is most consistent with nephrolithiasis/obstructing ureteral stone. In children the initial imaging test is ultrasound (no ionizing radiation, detects hydronephrosis and many stones); noncontrast CT KUB is reserved if ultrasound is nondiagnostic or clinical suspicion remains high.
raw_c:
Most appropriate next step: renal and bladder ultrasound.

Reasoning: The presentation (acute gross hematuria, sudden unilateral abdominal/flank pain, dysuria) with >100 RBC/hpf but no pyuria or nitrites points to a non‑infectious cause such as nephrolithiasis or obstructing lesion. In children the initial imaging test of choice is a renal/bladder ultrasound (to look for stones, hydronephrosis, or structural abnormalities); if ultrasound is nondiagnostic but suspicion remains high, proceed to low‑dose noncontrast CT. Urine culture is low yield here given lack of pyuria.
raw_d:
Renal (kidney and bladder) ultrasound.

Rationale: He has gross hematuria with flank-predominant abdominal pain and dysuria but no pyuria or nitrites to suggest UTI, making a noninfectious cause (eg, nephrolithiasis or structural lesion) more likely. In children the appropriate next step for suspected stone/obstructive pathology is renal ultrasound (CT reserved if ultrasound is nondiagnostic or high suspicion persists).

question: A 24-year-old woman in the intensive care unit for a severe asthma exacerbation is intubated and sedated while receiving intravenous steroids, continuous nebulized beta-agonists, and anticholinergic therapy. On the second hospital day, she develops a fever of 38.9°C (102.0°F), and a chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe consolidation. Blood cultures are obtained, and she is started empirically on intravenous cefepime and daptomycin. By hospital day four, she remains febrile, and a repeat chest X-ray shows worsening of the right lower lobe opacity. What is the most likely explanation for the failure of her treatment?
options: A. Delayed initiation of antibiotic therapy B. Development of resistance to the prescribed antibiotics C. Inadequate oxygenation of the affected lung tissue D. Drug interactions reducing the efficacy of the antibiotics E. The medicine cannot penetrate the organisms inside a walled-off abscess F. Infection with an organism not covered by the current antibiotics G. Inactivation of the medicine in the target tissue H. Subtherapeutic dosing of the antibiotics I. Immunosuppression caused by the patient's underlying condition J. Low bioavailability of the medicines
solution_text: Inactivation of the medicine in the target tissue
default: Daptomycin is ineffective for pneumonia because it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant. If MRSA pneumonia is suspected, vancomycin or linezolid should be used instead.
alternative: Immunosuppression caused by the patient's underlying condition
raw_a:
Most likely explanation: daptomycin is ineffective for pulmonary infections because it is inactivated by surfactant, so the MRSA coverage in her regimen would have failed to treat pneumonia. 

Cefepime covers gram‑negatives but if the pathogen were MRSA (or another gram‑positive) the daptomycin wouldn’t work in the lung; vancomycin or linezolid (or different broader coverage for VAP/aspiration) would be appropriate choices.
raw_b:
Conclusion: The regimen failed because daptomycin is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and thus cannot treat pneumonia — so the empiric therapy provided no effective anti‑MRSA lung coverage.

Reasoning: Cefepime covers gram‑negatives (including Pseudomonas) but not MRSA; daptomycin is active against MRSA in bloodstream/soft tissue but is functionally inactive in the alveolar space (binds/inactivated by surfactant). For MRSA pneumonia, vancomycin or linezolid should be used instead.
raw_c:
The daptomycin is ineffective for pulmonary infections because it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant. 

Reasoning: This is ventilator-associated pneumonia (after >48 h) where MRSA is a concern; cefepime covers gram‑negatives but not MRSA, and daptomycin—though active against MRSA in bloodstream/soft tissue—is rendered inactive in the lung. Vancomycin or linezolid should be used for MRSA pneumonia.
raw_d:
Conclusion: The treatment failed because daptomycin is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and thus is ineffective for treating pneumonia.

Brief reasoning: Daptomycin provides MRSA coverage for bacteremia/skin infections but binds pulmonary surfactant and loses activity in the lung, so the empiric regimen left the lung infection inadequately treated. Systemic steroids increase infection risk but do not explain why daptomycin specifically failed to clear a pulmonary consolidation.

question: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance with altered mental status. She is comatose but exhibits spontaneous deep and rapid breathing. Her vital sign are: temperature 100.2°F, blood pressure 92/54 mmHg, heart rate 103 bpm, respiratory rate 28, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Laboratory results include: WBC 12,700/µL, hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL, platelets 254,000/µL, sodium 137 mEq/L, potassium 4.2 mEq/L, chloride 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate 16 mEq/L, and creatinine 1.78 mg/dL. Arterial blood gas reveals pH 7.38, PaO2 94 mmHg, and PaCO2 26 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
options: A. Salicylate toxicity B. Medication overdose C. Acute kidney injury with uremia D. Alcohol binging E. Undiagnosed type 1 diabetes mellitus F. Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state G. Lactic acidosis due to hypoperfusion H. Starvation-induced ketoacidosis I. Early septic shock with metabolic compensation J. Severe sepsis
default:
Acute salicylate (aspirin) overdose. 

Reason: the normal pH with low HCO3 (16) and an inappropriately low PaCO2 (26; expected ≈ 1.5×HCO3+8 ≈ 32) indicates a mixed high‑anion‑gap metabolic acidosis plus respiratory alkalosis — the classic pattern of salicylate toxicity (early respiratory alkalosis from CNS respiratory center stimulation and later metabolic acidosis from accumulation of organic acids).
raw_a:
Most likely cause: acute salicylate (aspirin) overdose.

Reasoning: The patient has a high–anion gap metabolic acidosis (HCO3 16, AG ≈21) with an inappropriately low PaCO2 (26 mmHg). The pH is nearly normal because of a mixed disorder: metabolic acidosis plus a primary respiratory alkalosis (PaCO2 is lower than the expected respiratory compensation of ~32 mmHg). This combination—hyperventilation/respiratory alkalosis early with accumulating organic acids producing anion-gap metabolic acidosis—is classic for salicylate toxicity and fits the clinical picture (altered mental status, tachypnea, fever, renal impairment).
raw_b:
Most likely cause: acute salicylate (aspirin) intoxication.

Reasoning: labs show a high‑anion‑gap metabolic acidosis (AG = 137 − [100+16] = 21) with an inappropriately low PaCO2. Winter’s expected PaCO2 = 1.5×HCO3 + 8 ≈ 32 mmHg, but measured PaCO2 is 26 mmHg → indicates a concurrent primary respiratory alkalosis. The mixed metabolic acidosis + respiratory alkalosis with near‑normal pH is classic for salicylate poisoning (early respiratory alkalosis from central stimulation + metabolic acidosis from organic acids). Severe sepsis would more typically produce a lactic metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation rather than this mixed pattern.
raw_c:
Acute salicylate (aspirin) poisoning.

Reason: The labs show a metabolic acidosis (HCO3 16) with an inappropriately low PaCO2 (expected PaCO2 ≈ 1.5×HCO3+8 ≈ 32 mmHg but measured 26 mmHg), producing a near‑normal pH — classic for a mixed metabolic acidosis + primary respiratory alkalosis. The clinical picture (young adult with fever, tachypnea/hyperventilation, hypotension, AKI) is most consistent with salicylate overdose.
raw_d:
No — the most likely cause is salicylate (aspirin) overdose.

Reason: she has a mixed primary metabolic acidosis (HCO3 16, anion gap ≈21) plus an inappropriate respiratory alkalosis (PaCO2 26 — far lower than the expected ~40 by Winter’s formula), producing a near‑normal pH. That mixed picture (early respiratory alkalosis with a high‑anion‑gap metabolic acidosis) is classic for salicylate toxicity.

question: A 54-year-old male comes to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue and a 7-pound weight loss over the past month. His wife has noticed yellowing of his eyes, and he reports mild nausea without vomiting, abdominal pain, or stool changes. His medical history includes an episode of acute pancreatitis 10 years ago, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and obesity. He drinks two glasses of wine daily and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. Vital sign show temperature 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure 131/82 mmHg, pulse 81/min, and respirations 12/min. Physical examination reveals icteric sclera and a soft, non-tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory results show: - ALT: 67 U/L - AST: 54 U/L - Alkaline phosphatase: 771 U/L - Total bilirubin: 12.1 g/dL - Direct bilirubin: 9.4 g/dL What finding would most likely be observed on abdominal imaging?
options: A. Surface nodularity of the liver B. Acute choledocholithiasis C. Dilated intrahepatic bile ducts D. Hepatic hemangioma E. Distended gallbladder F. Pancreatic pseudocyst G. Gallbladder wall thickening H. Pancreatic mass with bile duct compression I. Chronic pancreatitis with calcifications J. Hepatic metastases
default: A mass in the head of the pancreas causing obstruction of the distal common bile duct — with dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct ("double-duct" sign) and often an enlarged, non-tender gallbladder (Courvoisier sign).
raw_a:
A mass in the head of the pancreas causing obstruction with dilation of the common bile duct (often with concomitant pancreatic duct dilation — the “double‑duct” sign).

Reason: Painless progressive cholestatic jaundice with weight loss is classic for pancreatic head cancer obstructing the distal bile duct; imaging typically shows a pancreatic head mass with upstream biliary (and often pancreatic) duct dilation (and may also show a distended, non‑tender gallbladder = Courvoisier sign).
raw_b:
